results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

results.description:
When in a disagreement, it is tempting to think that the other person must be foolish, malicious, or even insane to hold their position. This perspective might be a little unfair. Perhaps they in fact share many of your values and the disagreement is in some detail of how to attain them. Maybe they even know something we don't.

In this meetup we'll practice picking apart disagreements and figuring out which are the crucial pieces. What matters can we resolve that would resolve the overall disagreement? This process is useful for mediating many kinds of conflicts, both interpersonal and internal.

Our usual schedule is 


• 5:30-6pm Welcome everyone and discuss progress  on goals from last week. Order drinks and appetizers or dinner. 


• 6-7:00pm Focused discussion and work on our topic for the week. In addition to discussion of the theory, we really want to do exercises and make progress on real problems.


• 7-7:30pm Conclude and set individual goals for next meeting 


• 7:30-... Chat, mingle and leave whenever

Please bring something to write with and on.
results.how_to_find_us: We usually reserve a table in the back left. It should be easy to find.
results.name: Finding the Core of Disagreements

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

results.description:
What does it take to close the biggest of big deals?  Is it a a certain process, a unique methodology, special skills, a lot of luck, or some combination?


In this session, we will have some of the "Whale Hunting" pros of Enterprise Sales share their insights for how they have consistently closed seven and eight figure sized deals.  We will hear stories of the biggest deals they have closed as well as the deals that got away.


Our Panelists

·  Joseph Duffin – Global Business Development Manager, IBM Global Services

·  Morris Porter – Vice President of Worldwide Sales, Alpha Software

·  Stephen Viglione – Team Lead, Financial Services, Everbridge

As always, please share our event and community with your colleagues and friends in sales.  You can also share our event on http://entsale.co/whalehunting">Linkedin and Twitter.  Our hashtag is #BOSSales and Twitter account is @Enterprise_Sale­­.

If you are involved in enterprise sales or looking to position you and your company to sell into enterprises, this is the session to attend!

*******


About Our Panelists

Joseph Duffin is an IT sales experience with more than 30 years of experience.  Having worked for NCR/Teradata, Wang Laboratories and IBM, his tenure has allowed Joe to be a part of the global IT transformation.  Spending most of his sales career calling on major US financial services, healthcare, &  public sector accounts, he has also spent a number of years working in the Asia/Pacific and Latin American geographies within those industries. Joe has sold and partnered with sales teams that have resulted in contracts worth over $1 Billion in revenue.  Joe is currently the Global Sales Lead for the newly created IBM Sports and Entertainment practice.


Morris Porter is a strategic technology sales leader with 20+ years in sales and sales leadership roles. He is the Vice President of Worldwide Sales with Alpha Software, which provides a platform for building enterprise web and mobile applications.  Before Alpha, Morris served as VP of Sales at SiteSpect, where he revamped their sales process and drove substantially improved sales results.  Prior to that, Morris was VP of Sales and Business Development at web optimization company Yottaa, where he helped grow the startup to become a leader in their space. Previous to that, he ran Corporate Sales at Citrix SaaS to lead the expansion of the Citrix Corporate Sales team.  He was also with Intranets.com from startup to acquisition to WebEx and Cisco and at MCI/WorldCom and Metriplex.


</a>

<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/stephen-viglione-0131852">Stephen Viglione is a successful technology sales executive with over 17 years of experience selling technology solutions for early stage companies.  As a Sales Leader and a Senior Account Executive, Stephen has utilized a consultative approach to consistently exceed sales targets, grown his business and provided value to his clients.  Stephen is currently leading the Financial Services Team at Everbridge, a provider of a Global Critical Communications Platform utilized throughout large global organizations.  Prior to Everbridge, Stephen has held various Senior Sales roles at Cordys (acquired by OpenText), Inmagic (acquired by Lucidea), Attunity, Sungard, Dataware Solutions (acquired by Sungard) and Lumigent Technologies. 

*******

results.description:
This meetup is going to touch on three super hot topics: Angular 2, Redux state management and Reactive programming with RxJS. We have two speakers that will dive into these subjects an much more.

Diego Concha, @dapc85


Managing state and inter-component communication in complex front-end applications is a pain. MV* patterns leave you with state spread across your entire application and with a smorgasbord of options for component communication (callbacks, eventing, shared services, etc…). Redux provides a compelling solution for both of these challenges by evolving on the ideas of Facebook's Flux architecture and adding others from the Elm language.  

Redux gives you a single source of truth for your UI's state and a simple subscription mechanism for components. The entire UI is generated from this state tree and components subscribe to changes in a the slice of state that they care about regardless of what caused that slice to change. It goes a step further in simplifying the data flow mental-model by serializing/synchronizing all state updates. This makes UI changes easy to log and apply forward and backward in time (ie time travel debugging). 

Not only will we do a motivating introduction but we'll also discuss best practices when applying Redux to Angular 1.x applications. 

Jeff Whelpley, @jeffwhelpley

I have gone through a half dozen different iterations of Redux in my Angular 2 app, most recently settling on a variation that includes the ngrx library which has a Reactive slant on redux. I will get into the advantages and disadvantages with different types of state management approaches. I will also show some of the code that I have been working on for GetHuman.

------------------ 


Schedule:

6:00pm - Doors open for everyone; pizza and beverages available


7pm - Diego's talk

7:45pm - Jeff's talk

8:15pm to 8:30pm - Networking, clean-up, bye!

------------------

Address: 290 Congress Street, Boston MA

Google Maps: 
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Brightcove/@42.3533402,-71.052391,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x832a579c43c8b7da

Public Transit: South Station, head north on Atlantic Ave 1 block, right on Congress Street.

Parking: There is a garage at 284 Congress. Discounted parking at night after 6.
Also: http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/290_congress_street_boston_ma_united_states/?ac=1&country=US&lat=42.3532702&lng=-71.05255590000002

results.description:
6:30 to 7:00 PM - Networking

7:00 to 7:15 PM - Lightning Talks

• "Quantifying a meal" - Miguel Alonso-Alonso MD PhD

• "Edit-run-repeat: Stop the cycle of pain" - Peter Bull


7:15 to 8:00 PM - Talk and Q&A

-   Riding on large data with scikit-learn out-of-core algorithms

In recent years, Data Science has focused primarily on Big Data tools and analytics. At the same time, Small Data platforms have also witnessed  gradual  enhancement providing  end user with better tools for analysis and insight.

But, what about data that doesn't fit neatly into the current categorization of Small or Big Data? What if you had data that was too big to fit into the memory of the  local machine and too small to justify Big Data solutions.

Termed Large Data, several solutions exist to overcome this  quagmire. Amazon EC2, H20, Dato's, Graphlab Create and R Streaming Package all provide services with Large Data in mind.

However, an often overlooked tool is Scikit-Learn. Scikit- Learn is an open source machine learning library for Python programming language.  Developed to optimize smaller data, it nevertheless provides a decent set of algorithms for out-of-core classification, regression, clustering and decomposition.

In this talk, Alex Perrier  will focus on scikit-learn out-of-core algorithms and explore their performances in the context of large data.

About Speaker:

Alex Perrier is Data Scientist and Software Engineer with a strong Mathematical and Signal Processing background, a solid experience in Agile software development and a passion for Stochastic processes. He currently works for Berklee Online  as  Data and Software Lead. Alex  holds a Ph. D. from Telecom Paris Tech, with a focus on Signal processing, Mathematics, Stochastic Processes.
results.name: Riding on large data with Scikit-Learn Out-of-Core Algorithms

        -   Riding on large data with scikit-learn out-of-core algorithms

In recent years, Data Science has focused primarily on Big Data tools and analytics. At the same time, Small Data platforms have also witnessed  gradual  enhancement providing  end user with better tools for analysis and insight.


But, what about data that doesn't fit neatly into the current categorization of Small or Big Data? What if you had data that was too big to fit into the memory of the  local machine and too small to justify Big Data solutions.

Termed Large Data, several solutions exist to overcome this  quagmire. Amazon EC2, H20, Dato's, Graphlab Create and R Streaming Package all provide services with Large Data in mind.


However, an often overlooked tool is Scikit-Learn. Scikit- Learn is an open source machine learning library for Python programming language.  Developed to optimize smaller data, it nevertheless provides a decent set of algorithms for out-of-core classification, regression, clustering and decomposition.

In this talk, Alex Perrier  will focus on scikit-learn out-of-core algorithms and explore their performances in the context of large data.


About Speaker:

Alex Perrier is Data Scientist and Software Engineer with a strong Mathematical and Signal Processing background, a solid experience in Agile software development and a passion for Stochastic processes. He currently works for Berklee Online  as  Data and Software Lead. Alex  holds a Ph. D. from Telecom Paris Tech, with a focus on Signal processing, Mathematics, Stochastic Processes.
results.name: Riding on large data with Scikit-Learn Out-of-Core Algorithms

results.description:
*** IF INTERESTED YOU NEED TO REGISTER THROUGH EVENTBRITE *** 

*** LIMITED SEATING, SO APPLY NOW ***

Making Livestreams and Videos More Informative

What if you could add news stories, image, videos and tweets to live video to make it more informative and engaging? How would this change the way we experience events such as breaking news? Deepstream.tv is a new platform recently deployed in beta that makes it easier to find livestreams and add relevant contextual information to them. The result is a beautiful, responsive player that lets viewers browse your curated information without leaving the video player window.

Gordon Mangum, Research Assistant at the Center for Civic Media at MIT’s Media Lab will run a training workshop to demonstrate the features and capabilities of this platform. We will find interesting videos and/or livestreams, use Deepstream to add relevant media, and demonstrate how this curated video-based news can be embedded on any website. Our focus will be on newsroom and independent journalist applications, but anyone who is interested is welcome!

WHEN: Wednesday, March 16, 2016 from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM  

WHERE: MIT Media Lab E15-341 - 75 Amherst St. Cambridge, MA 02139:
results.name: DeepStream Workshop: Making Livestreams and Videos More Informative

results.description:
Communicate Your Benefits to the People Who Really Matter for Your Career Advancement


Your career advancement is determined not only by the quality of your work but also by having the right people know about your work. Too often, Asian professionals focus on doing the work without taking the necessary time to promote their contribution to their managers and organization. Similarly, career advancement success is also about networking with external parties so you can assess your market value and change employers when it is strategic and beneficial to your career growth. You'll walk away from this workshop with critical strategies for career advancement that is often overlooked by Asian professionals.*

Please join NAAAP Boston for an interactive workshop. Light refreshment and snack will be provided. This event is sponsored by Capital One Cafe. 

Tickets are available here: Eventbrite link

Agenda:

6:30 - 7:00 - registration and dinner

7:00 - 7:15 - welcome and introduction 

7:15 - 8:45 - networking workshop

8:45 - 9:00 - Q&A

=====================================


*By attending the workshop, you will receive a discount to Judy’s seminar series in April, called, “Advancing Your Career as a Power-Structure Outsider”

=====================================


ABOUT THE SPEAKER
Judy Shen-Filerman is CEO of Dreambridge Partners, LLC. Judy founded her leadership training and coaching ﬁrm to enable advancement success for executives, professionals and students who are “culture-crossers” in the American workplace. Judy has over 25 years of experience as a marketing executive, consultant and entrepreneur. An accomplished leader, Judy led innovative businesses at Procter & Gamble, Campbell Soup Asia and Polaroid, in the US and overseas. Judy progressed quickly in her corporate career to become the youngest Vice President at Polaroid. Judy’s coaching incorporates her ﬁrst-hand experience as a bi-lingual, immigrant woman who navigated myriad challenges to achieve corporate success. She engages clients to take actions that align with their cultural core values while achieving practical goals for their careers and organizations. Judy consistently receives rave reviews for her lectures, leadership development engagements and diversity and inclusion initiatives, whether at global organizations, leading US business schools or start-up ventures. Judy writes extensively about leadership, career and culture. She coaches MBA and Executives at Harvard Business School, is a regular contributor to The Boston Globe Job Doc Chat, has been featured in numerous professional and national publications. A Harvard College and Harvard Business School graduate, Judy passionately leverages her experiential knowledge as a successful cross-cultural leader to help others reach their dreams. Judy lives in the Boston area with her husband and two children.

results.description:
Greetings everyone - mark your calendars now for our March OpenStack Meetup. Note the Wed date!

PLUMgrid joins us as co-sponsor and I know you will enjoy a dynamic session with our lead speaker Fernando Sanchez.


It has been demonstrated that it is relatively easy to launch tens of thousands of containers on a group of hosts. But what new demands do containers at scale put on your virtual network infrastructure? At this meetup, PLUMgrid will discuss how Neutron can provide network functionalities for containers and how and if CNI (Container Network Interface), CNM (Container Network Model) and other network models fit into OpenStack to solve the pressing security and scale requirements of containers. Join us for an evening of intriguing topics, and free food! 

PRESENTER: Fernando Sanchez is a Principal Systems Engineeer at PLUMgrid where he works in implementing software networking infrastructures in his customer's clouds. Fernando has 15 years experience in designing, implementing and operating large-scale networks of virtually all kinds of customers ranging from tier-1 telcos to massive datacenters and enterprises. Fernando became an engineer in his natal Spain and since then has gained certifications from virtually every vendor he's worked with, including Alcatel-Lucent, Brocade, Force10 or Vyatta.


Reminders:

• A light dinner and soft drinks will be provided courtesy of PLUMgrid  ~ 6:15pm and we will kick off the sessions ~ 7:00pm.

• If you are interested in giving a Lightening Talk shoot us a note with a topic or just come to the session ready to speak!

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.
results.name: Container Networking in OpenStack: Containers-as-a-Service

results.description:
Rick Landwehr will be leading this Mindful Beat meditation. This is a meditation to a simple beat using drums or other percussion instruments. Our event start time is 6:45pm. But please arrive early to settle in. 

Space is limited to 15. Please do not RSVP unless you are committed to coming. Your spot would be valuable to others who want to participate. 8)

Our schedule:
6:30pm - It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat. We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store.
6:45pm - Class starts.
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm. At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking.
8:00pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) experience the Mindful Beat meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 


More info:
Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.
http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/ 

What to bring:
You can bring your own drum, or borrow a drum from Ten Thousand Villages stock (depending upon availability). Low pitched drums work best for this meditation. This is not a drum circle, but a way of focusing on the present moment using simple, repetitive rhythm. No drumming experience or technique is required. 

It's fine to just show up as you are. 
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor. Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything.

If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and can accommodate 15 spots for this event.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Mindful Beat!

We’re super excited to have Regina Obe and Leo Hsu lead this month’s Maptime tutorial on PostGIS (http://postgis.net), a geospatial extension for the PostgreSQL database. They are co-authors of "PostGIS in Action".


This is the meetup that was originally scheduled for January.

If you get a chance, please install PostGIS before the meetup by following these instructions for Mac and Windows users: 

http://www.postgis.us/presentations/postgis_install_guide_22.html

--------


Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.


This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.


Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?


Maptime is hands-on, so don't forget to bring your laptop!

results.description:
Let's make some Happiness Jars ......

You can be as creative as you wish!  Canning jars, wooden craft books or banks, etc.  bring items to decorate them (stickers etc.)

Cost:  $5.00

A happiness jar is a project inspired by Elizabeth Gilbert, the author of 

Eat, Pray, Love

It's a simple way of reminding yourself every day of the good that came out of your day, even if the day has been a challenge.

Every day, think of something that made you happy. It could be something that happened that very day, but it could really be anything. Be truthful to yourself; the simpler things that delighted you are often the happiest moments.Set aside your cultural, faith-based understandings of "prayers/luck/wishes", etc. that seek happiness; also set aside any inner voice criticisms about happiness. One of the things that may impact your use of the jar is prior understandings or inculcated messaging about what "rules" you need to follow to get the jar to "work". The thing is, there are no rules. The jar is to serve you, rather than you serving the ritual.If you want to put other things in the jar, like a lucky token, ticket stub from a trip you loved or a note from a loved one, go ahead. It's your jar and your fulfillment.A variation of this concept is to focus on happy moments from a certain relationship in your life, like your relationship with your mate, or your children. A couple, for example, can commit to writing down things they love about each other every day and depositing the notes into the same jar.


Write it down on a piece of paper. Find scraps of paper suitable for writing a small message on. You could go to the effort of making a pile of ready-made pieces of paper (this can be a good motivator to keep doing this each day) or you could simply rip a piece of paper from a napkin, junk mail, or similar, as needed.If you can't find a piece of paper, write your note on your phone. Send a text message or e-mail to yourself and remember to transcribe it later, so you can put a physical note in the jar.


Make deposits into the happiness jar daily. The idea is somewhat to use it daily but life can get busy and events intervene, so if you miss days, don't be fussed; just pick it up from where you left off.Set a daily reminder or alarm on your phone.Keep the jar in a safe place where it's less likely to be bumped or in the way of everyday activities but ideally, it should be in sight to remind you to use it.If the jar has a lid, keep the lid on in case it gets knocked over. This also keeps the dust out, especially important if your jar is very large and will be sitting in the same spot for months or years.


Read the messages when life gets tough. This is the most wonderful part of using a happiness jar. When you feel that everything is getting to you and that there isn't much happiness in your life, take out a few of the messages and read them through. These reminders of the happiness that has been in your life and will continue to be present in your life will serve as a source of morale boosting. Your past happiness will comfort you and give you hope that there is more to come. It will also remind you that happiness is found in moments along the journey and is not a single destination with any defined point or actions.Some people enjoy starting a new happiness jar every year, and reading the contents at the end of the year. Consider making a collage or scrapbook of all your notes.


I will be cross posting this event with North Shore Law of Attraction, which is a mixed group.

Please be respectful of event organizers, no same day cancellations, they will count as a no show.
results.name: Gratuity/Happiness Jars

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 18: Action in the Passing of Time, of the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly reading and questions.

Please note the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], our Director of Events, with any questions.

READING: Part 4, Chapter 18: Action in the Passing of Time
https://mises.org/library/human-action-0/html/p/800

QUESTIONS:

1) Why are the period of production and the duration of serviceableness categories of human action? 

2) What does the choice of a longer period of production imply?

3) Which undeniable fact provides the basis for the concept of time preference?

4) How does time preference restrict the amount of saving and investment?

5) Why did economists err in classifying capital as an independent factor of production?

6) How does foreign capital help poorer nations, and how does the supply of capital determine the standard of living?

7) Why can't there be "free" capital?

8) Why are technological backwardness and economic inferiority two different things?

9) Why is capital a praxeological concept, and how does it differ from the Marxian notion of capital?

10) Why can capital only be accumulated by individuals, and in which ways?

11) Can capital flight harm the balance of payments?

12) How does hoarding influence the accumulation of capital?
results.name: Action In The Passage Of Time

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.

Join us for networking, food, and an amazing speaker that will help you come up with a one page strategic plan.  Since we will be having a private room, please plan on supporting the restaurant and buying a drink or food item.  Also, if you did not pay dues for meetup costs at our February event, please bring $5.


Wake Up Your Business

The Road Map to Growth in Your Business:

The One Page Strategic Plan

For Small to Medium Size Businesses

Have you noticed that the bigger your business gets, the harder it is to grow to the next level, or that you just cannot get beyond a certain size? If this resonates with you then join us to learn how to develop and use a One Page Strategic Plan to set goals and serve as the road map to achieving the performance you want our of your business. Learn how to create a dynamic, living Strategic Plan and how to leverage it for success. The one page Strategic Plan encourages simplicity and organizational alignment with the following elements:

 SWOT Alignment and Analysis

 Core Values and Beliefs

 Purpose (Why we exist) Statement

 BHAG – Big Hairy Audacious Goal

 Targets, Goals, Actions (3-5 year, 1 year, Quarterly)

Ken Erdelt, AdviCoach (http://kerdelt.advicoach.com)As an AdviCoach, I coach the owners of privately held and family-owned businesses and I can help you grow your profits by at least 68% per year and build a team to help run the business for you so you canget some time back for yourself.
results.name: Wake Up Your Business  The Road Map to Growth in Your Business:

The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!

results.description:
Democracy requires that elections have credible results -- otherwise the winner lacks a political mandate and the supporters of losing candidates react with anything from protests to revolution.

Yet (U.S.) elections have become larger and increasingly complex, and politics seems more polarized. Software-based voting systems inspire little trust. Voting systems purchased with funds allocated after the 2000 U.S. presidential election fiasco are rapidly becoming obsolete.

How can good definitions, statistics, and cryptography help?

We present the notion of software independence, describe several methods for effective auditing of paper ballots, and give an overview of "end-to-end'' cryptographic voting systems that allow voters to confirm that their votes were counted exactly as intended, without violating voter privacy or enabling vote-selling. We close with a (pessimistic) assessment of the prospects for "voting over the internet".

This is a joint meeting of GBC/ACM and the IEEE Computer and Social Implications of Technology Societies.


<a href="http://ewh.ieee.org/r1/boston/computer/rivest.jpg%22"></a>

Professor Rivest is an Institute Professor at MIT, a member of its Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, a member of MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), a member of that lab's Theory of Computation Group and a leader of its Cryptography and Information Security Group.

He received a B.A. in Mathematics from Yale University in 1969, and a Ph.D. in Computer Science from Stanford University in 1974. His research interests include cryptography, computer and network security, algorithms, and voting system security.

Rivest is a co-inventor of the RSA public-key cryptosystem, has extensive experience in cryptographic design and cryptanalysis. He is also a founder of RSA Data Security and of Verisign. Together with Adi Shamir and Len Adleman, he has received the 2002 ACM Turing Award and the 2009 NEC C&C Award.

He is also well-known as a co-author of the text, Introduction to Algorithms (with Cormen, Leiseron, and Stein).

He is a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences, and is a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, the International Association for Cryptographic Research, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is on the Advisory Board for the Electronic Privacy Information Center and on the board of Verified Voting.
results.how_to_find_us: This meeting will be held in the main auditorium on the 1st floor of the Broad Institute, corner of Main and Vassar Streets in Cambridge.
results.name: Auditability and Verification of Elections with Prof. Ronald L. Rivest, MIT

results.description:
This month, we're back to our standard two speaker format.


Stuart Popejoy will be giving a talk about composing music using Haskell, and Adam Wespiser will be giving a talk on using Haskell in the financial industry.

We will need to start at 7pm Sharp, just in case Akamai is strict on having us leave at 9.


7:00-8:00: Adam Wespiser - Creating a Domain Specific Language to Analyze Financial Data

In the course of my work two interesting problems have come up designing a DSL for data analysis: generalizing built-in operations to accept vectorized objects, and abstract data frame object for aggregation. The aim of this talk is to share my code, specifically an evaluation strategy for primitive data types, to demonstrate how we can write languages expressive enough for domain experts to extract meaningful insight. More broadly, this talk will cover 3 issues: Programming language design, exploration of data, and Haskell for industry applications.

8:00-9:00: Stuart Popejoy - Composing (Music) in Haskell with Braids, Isos and XSDs

Making a computer "talk music" is hard. Modelling musical data in code is ungainly, leading to highly opinionated and stylized DSLs. "Fadno", an umbrella project for music composition, seeks to leverage Haskell's facility for translation between structures and representations. It offers output to MusicXML via a reasonably ambitious attempt to model any XSD schema as a type model. Finally, it presents work in using braid theory as a generative model for music composition, including braid moves as infinite (co)data.

Speaker Bios:


Adam Wespiser:


Adam is a software developer at Elsen, (elsen.co), a Boston based start-up  using Haskell to make portfolio analysis faster and easier.  Previously, Adam was a biology researcher: focusing on how to apply statistical methods on large data sets to better understand the human genome. His interests include programming language design, statistics, machine learning, type theory, and start-up engineering. http://github.com/adamwespiser/resume

Stuart Popejoy:

Stuart Popejoy is a musician and software engineer in Brooklyn, NY. He leads a Haskell group at JP Morgan working on blockchain technologies, which recently open-sourced three projects: Juno, Masala and Hopper. His background is in trading and exchange systems, involving low-latency engineering and distributed systems. He is an active player in the NYC creative music scene, leading the avant-metal band "Bassoon" and participating in numerous improv, jazz and noise projects. Notable collaborators include Sarah Bernstein, Mick Barr, Kris Davis, Ches Smith, Ron Anderson, Chris Cochrane and Brian Chase.

Logistics: 

If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.

Food:

Pizzas, salad and soda.

Afterwards:

If you'd like to stick around, a number of us tend to head down to the CBC or another pub afterwards to socialize. If you would like to give a talk or if you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to follow up here or email one of the organizers.
results.how_to_find_us: Simply come to the front door of Akamai. If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.
results.name: Talks by Stuart Popejoy and Adam Wespiser

The oldest of humankind’s experiments with fermentation, and certainly one of the most delicious, mead is a special alchemy of honey and yeasts. Not just another alcohol, mead is an excellent carrier for the medicinal actions of herbs! In fact, one of the names for herb-infused mead, metheglin, speaks to its original use as a folk medicine.

In this class we’ll demonstrate the basic mead-making process, and share our experiences with introducing herbs at various stages of the fermentation process. You’ll be brewing your own in no time!

results.description:
Let's make some Happiness Jars ......

You can be as creative as you wish!  Canning jars, wooden craft books or banks, etc.  bring items to decorate them (stickers etc.)

Cost:  $5.00

A Happiness jar is a project inspired by Elizabeth Gilbert, the author of 

Eat, Pray, Love

It's a simple way of reminding yourself every day of the good that came out of your day, even if the day has been a challenge.

Every day, think of something that made you happy. It could be something that happened that very day, but it could really be anything. Be truthful to yourself; the simpler things that delighted you are often the happiest moments.Set aside your cultural, faith-based understandings of "prayers/luck/wishes", etc. that seek happiness; also set aside any inner voice criticisms about happiness. One of the things that may impact your use of the jar is prior understandings or inculcated messaging about what "rules" you need to follow to get the jar to "work". The thing is, there are no rules. The jar is to serve you, rather than you serving the ritual.If you want to put other things in the jar, like a lucky token, ticket stub from a trip you loved or a note from a loved one, go ahead. It's your jar and your fulfillment.A variation of this concept is to focus on happy moments from a certain relationship in your life, like your relationship with your mate, or your children. A couple, for example, can commit to writing down things they love about each other every day and depositing the notes into the same jar.

Write it down on a piece of paper. Find scraps of paper suitable for writing a small message on. You could go to the effort of making a pile of ready-made pieces of paper (this can be a good motivator to keep doing this each day) or you could simply rip a piece of paper from a napkin, junk mail, or similar, as needed.If you can't find a piece of paper, write your note on your phone. Send a text message or e-mail to yourself and remember to transcribe it later, so you can put a physical note in the jar.

Make deposits into the happiness jar daily. The idea is somewhat to use it daily but life can get busy and events intervene, so if you miss days, don't be fussed; just pick it up from where you left off.Set a daily reminder or alarm on your phone.Keep the jar in a safe place where it's less likely to be bumped or in the way of everyday activities but ideally, it should be in sight to remind you to use it.If the jar has a lid, keep the lid on in case it gets knocked over. This also keeps the dust out, especially important if your jar is very large and will be sitting in the same spot for months or years.

Read the messages when life gets tough. This is the most wonderful part of using a happiness jar. When you feel that everything is getting to you and that there isn't much happiness in your life, take out a few of the messages and read them through. These reminders of the happiness that has been in your life and will continue to be present in your life will serve as a source of morale boosting. Your past happiness will comfort you and give you hope that there is more to come. It will also remind you that happiness is found in moments along the journey and is not a single destination with any defined point or actions.Some people enjoy starting a new happiness jar every year, and reading the contents at the end of the year. Consider making a collage or scrapbook of all your notes.


with Love & Gratitude

Ellen Sklaver, Facilitator [masked])


Sue, Event Host

Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

The program starts promptly at 7:30pm during the fall and winter months,and 8:30pm during the spring and summer months.

Please arrive early as there is no admittance once the program begins.

We start admitting ticketed guests 10 minutes before the program begins.

Right before the program starts and after all the ticketed guests that are present are admitted, we will admit any non-ticketed guests until we reach capacity.

Weather
The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here. Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory): no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time.

Location
The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Avenue in Boston, MA, above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell up to the Observatory is on the fifth floor just to the left of room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.

Information
For information about Open Night, please call[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory):

Source(s):
New member, Manny reminded me about...
http://www.bostonastronomy.net/Public%20Viewing.html
http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/

Watch for tickets here:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-university-open-night-tickets-20559405736
results.name: Boston University - Public Open Night at the Coit Observatory

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:

Organizer/Event Host: 
Jenna (*SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor: 
Wendel C.

Sponsored by: 
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location: 
Abington

Cost: 
$15.00 with Kangoo Jumps rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.

Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP: 
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.

Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- What happens in Kangoo club stays in Kangoo club - pls don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

.- There is no secure place to put your things, open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

 - Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite - Bring a healthy snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

* Future Kangoo Jump Events: 
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 


Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

The focus is to be present in the moment, allowing thoughts and emotions to surface. We become an internal observer of these, fostering healthy non-attachment and cultivating a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend.

It's a gentle, relaxing class in which we will do light movements to release tension from organs, neck, hips & joints. We will use the wooden pillow on various parts of our body to relieve stress and feel more relaxed & comfortable.

What is the Wooden Pillow?
The Wooden Pillow can be used to adjust the neck and straighten the vertebrae. With proper use, it enhances blood and energy circulation to the brain. It can also be utilized for intestinal healing and foot massage. The wooden pillow is a great tool for deep sleep.

*This class will be approximately 1 hr. Please try to arrive 10 minutes early for warmup. (Cost = $5.00, paid upon arrival)

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
***Please update your RSVP and indicate what time you expect to arrive for meeting and coordination! If your plans have changed update your RSVP.

Cover charge of $10.00 starts during the afternoon when there will be live music on both floors. So if you want to avoid the cover charge be there before. If you plan to stay a while and order food We suggest putting your name in for a table. Wear Green,

A large group of us attended each of the last 5 years. This year St Patricks Day is on a Thursday. 

The Red Sox Natives are going Green on Thursday, March 17 to celebrate St Patrick's Day at Harrington's Food and Spirits in downtown Wakefield. Harrington's is a cozy Irish Restaurant and Pub with two floors. We have been there before. The food is great!

Harrington's is all Irish, all day, all night, on both floors. There is live entertainment all afternoon and night at Harrington's led by the owner Dan's band Casterbridge Union and Terry Weir and others. There is a $10.00 cover starting during the afternoon.

Wear your Green and be there at 4:00 pm or earlier or whenever. The place will be packed all day and all night! We suggest any RSVPs coordinate by E Mail to meet other attendees at whatever times works best. Please RSVP and let us know approximately what time you will join us! Some of us will be there well into the evening just like prior years.

There is free parking in downtown Wakefield in the public lot across from Harrington's and along Water and Main Streets. The location is T accessible by the 136 and 137 Bus from the Orange Line in Malden Center. And Commuter Rail accessible from North Station via the Reading and Haverhill Trains stopping at Wakefield with a less than 10 minute walk up Albion to Main to Water Street.

Please remember to pay in cash as you order or maintain your own bar tab and settle with your server.

<a href="http://www.harringtonspub.com"></a>

We hope to see you there.
results.name: Green Red Sox Natives Celebrate St. Patrick's Day at Harrington's Irish Pub

results.description:
Anyone interested in a Boston St. Patty's Day meet-up on an Introduction to Apache Kudu, Storage for Fast Analytics on Fast Data. If so, please RSVP here. 

Oh and Todd Lipcon will be presenting! Special thanks to EnerNOC for providing the meet-up space. Food & BEER will be provide, it's St. Patty's Day in Boston after all!

Agenda:


• 530-6pm Food, drinks and Networking

• 6-7pm Apache Kudu presentation

• 7-730pm Networking

Speaker bio: 

Todd Lipcon is an engineer at Cloudera, where he primarily contributes to open source distributed systems in the Apache Hadoop ecosystem. He is a committer and a PMC member on the Apache Hadoop, HBase, and Thrift projects. Prior to Cloudera, Todd worked on web infrastructure at several startups and researched novel machine-learning methods for collaborative filtering. Todd received his bachelor’s degree with honors from Brown University.

Introduction to Apache Kudu


Over the past several years, the Hadoop ecosystem has made great strides in its real-time access capabilities, narrowing the gap compared to traditional database technologies. With systems such as Impala and Spark, analysts can now run complex queries or jobs over large datasets within a matter of seconds. With systems such as Apache HBase and Apache Phoenix, applications can achieve millisecond-scale random access to arbitrarily-sized datasets.

Despite these advances, some important gaps remain that prevent many applications from transitioning to Hadoop-based architectures. Users are often caught between a rock and a hard place: columnar formats such as Apache Parquet offer extremely fast scan rates for analytics, but little to no ability for real-time modification or row-by-row indexed access. Online systems such as HBase offer very fast random access, but scan rates that are too slow for large scale data warehousing workloads.

This talk will investigate the trade-offs between real-time transactional access and fast analytic performance from the perspective of storage engine internals. It will also describe and demo Apache Kudu, the new addition to the open source Hadoop ecosystem that fills the gap described above, complementing HDFS and HBase to provide a new option to achieve fast scans and fast random access from a single API.
results.name: St. Patty's Day meet-up on an Introduction to Apache Kudu

results.description:
Monthly Meeting - Funding your deals

***New meeting location - Marriot, 95 Station Landing, Medford, MA


5:30 PM - Open networking, bring LOTS of business cards

6:30 PM - Meeting, forced networking, Deal of the month, Market update with Dickens and marketing tip of the month!


Matt McLoughlin with Boston Property Capital will cover funding your deals with private money.  It would be nice if rehabbers had access to an endless supply of their own money to fund their deals.  But, they don't and most of them feel like it's better to use OPM (other people's money) even when they have their own money to fund a deal.  They do this so they are prepared if another deal comes up during the process of the current deal.  Always good to have working capital. 


http://c3155192.r92.cf0.rackcdn.com/ckeditor_assets/pictures/root/38686/content_Matt_McLoughin.JPG

Since 2003 Matt McLoughlin has developed a broad-base and principled expertise in investment, sales and rentals of the Boston real estate market. Matt graduated from Salem State University with a degree in business and a minor in computer science. His real estate experience ranges from buying foreclosed house, working as a sales agent all the way to operations manag

er with a

national luxury apartment company.

Matt´s knowledge of multiple facets of real estate business contributes to his success as the senior lender for Boston Property Capital. He is a member of the National Association of Realtors and is a licensed Massachusetts Real Estate Instructor and Director of the Patriot Real Estate School.

Matt recently bought a house in Scituate where he enjoys his family,
playing basketball at local courts, and playing his guitar.


Free for members of BostonAREIA.com; $25 for nonmembers (members of this meetup are not members of BostonAREIA.com)
results.why: You found a deal, now how do you fund it???
results.name: Matt McLoughlin - funding your deals with private money

results.description:
One of the great things about the Business Model Generation canvas is that it is extremely flexible. It can be used for information technology, green technology or biotech. And it can even be used for show business. Feature film director Matthew Martino utilized the Business Model Generation canvas to pitch and raise money for his feature film project Chainsaw Maidens from Hell. Shot in the summer of 2014 it debuted this past fall and is currently making the international film market circuit represented by Hollywood sales agents. We invite you now to learn how Matthew applied Business Model Generation in the entertainment field.

Matthew will show clips from the movie and talk about what went on behind the scenes. We'll do some group work using techniques of Business Model Generation - either for your own businesses, or even for your own feature movie ideas. This will be a great session for business professionals and movie buffs alike.

Thanks to WeWork Fort Point for providing the space for this event and letting us tap into their keg, and to GYK Antler for feeding us. Pizza will be served.

Links:
http://www.ChainsawMaidensfromhell.com
http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4196576
http://www.thefilmcatalogue.com/catalog/FilmDetail.php?id=22124

results.description:
6:00-7:00 Networking, Introductions, Food and Refreshments

7:00-7:45 Citrix at Scale - Real World Intelligenct for Deployments Mini to Mammoth

Description: 

After spending years designing, building, and supporting some of the largest Citrix implementations in the world I've seen some crazy stuff.  Sometimes I've even been the one doing the crazy!  Poor design decisions can doom a virtualization project, especially at a larger scale. In this session I will talk about the challenges and opportunities virtual technologies bring to the Enterprise.  I'll discuss common sense strategies to approach designing your environment, the joys of automation in the provisioning process, and what I think is the future of virtualization in the environment (hint: It's all about the apps).I want you to walk away ready to avoid the mistakes I've made and able to focus on the things that are most important to your deployment.

Speaker Bio

Paul Stansel, Principal Consultant, Presidio

Paul Stansel is an 18-year veteran of virtualization technologies who has installed every version of Citrix since WinFrame. He has designed, implemented, and supported Citrix environments for multiple Fortune 100 companies primarily in the Insurance and Pharmaceutical verticals. Paul is currently a Principal Consultant at Presidio and was previously an Enterprise Infrastructure Architect specializing in Virtualization and Cloud Technologies for Travelers and the Lead Virtualization Architect for Aetna where he built from the ground up Aetna's 55,000 seat global XenApp and XenDesktop environment spanning 5 datacenters across the globe. Over the years, Paul has been an author and editor for several books on Citrix and Microsoft technologies as well as a featured writer for several popular websites. He has been a speaker at Citrix Synergy and PremierCIO and in his spare time blogs at 

citrixtips.com

 and on twitter @pstansel. Paul holds multiple Citrix certifications and is a current Citrix Technology Professional (CTP).


8:00-8:45: TBD TBD
results.how_to_find_us: www.virtg.com
results.name: The best education in Virtualization each month!

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.
results.how_to_find_us: Go to middle floor - meeting room is on parking-lot side of the building. MeetUp sign will be on door.
results.name: Options Monthly Meeting for Boston Traders Meetup

results.description:
http://pivotal.io/event/spring-cloud-data-flow/boston

Pivotal Boston is hosting a special Spring meetup on St. Patrick’s Day at our new Cambridge location in Kendall Square—the heart of technology leadership, entrepreneurship, education, and innovative research in Boston.

Join us for some microbrews, a tour of our new space, networking with your peers from the Spring community and a talk on Streaming and Batch Processing in the Cloud with Data Microservices, led by Mark Fisher, Senior Engineer of Pivotal’s Spring Cloud team and author of Spring Integration in Action.

Talk Summary
The future of scalable data processing is microservices! Building on the ease of development and deployment provided by Spring Boot and the cloud native capabilities of Spring Cloud, the Spring Cloud Stream and Spring Cloud Task projects provide a simple and powerful framework for creating microservices for stream and batch processing. They make it easy to develop data-processing Spring Boot applications that build upon the capabilities of Spring Integration and Spring Batch, respectively. At a higher level of abstraction, Spring Cloud Data Flow is an integrated orchestration layer that provides a highly productive experience for deploying and managing sophisticated data pipelines consisting of standalone microservices. Streams and tasks are defined using a DSL abstraction and can be managed via shell and a web UI. Furthermore, a pluggable runtime SPI allows Spring Cloud Data Flow to coordinate these applications across a variety of distributed runtime platforms such as Apache YARN, Cloud Foundry, or Apache Mesos. This session will provide an overview of these projects, including how they evolved out of Spring XD. Both streaming and batch-oriented applications will be deployed in live demos on different platforms ranging from local cluster to a remote Cloud to show the simplicity of the developer experience.
results.name: Microbrews and Microservices event!

venue.name: Microsoft New England Research & Development Center (NERD)

results.description:
Come join David Pileggi as he talkd about Office 365 and IT. 

IT departments world wide have become to manage and maintain as the number of systems continue to increase. Adding to the burden some legacy systems are tied to older operating systems, versions of office, Internet Explorer, etc. Stress between the business stakeholders and IT has continued to escalate as more systems are demanded on a department that is expected to run with a skeleton crew. Something has to give... something has to release the pressure that is being felt company wide globally. This session will delve into how O365 can be a great foundation to make available what the business stakeholders need while relieving the building stress on your IT department.​
results.how_to_find_us: 1st floor
results.name: Using Office 365 to Streamline Your IT

results.description:
Dan Hermes, author of Xamarin Mobile Application Development, talks about how to give your users what they need to get around your Xamarin app quickly, moving from screen to screen with confidence and ease. Menus, tappable icons, buttons, tabs, and lists all offer ways to navigate your app. Dan will discuss industry-standard approaches for tying an app’s screens together in elegant and usable ways called navigation design patterns, based upon the concepts in his new book. Here are the most common mobile UI navigation patterns used in Xamarin development:

• Hierarchical

• Modal

• Drill-down list

• Navigation drawer

• Tabs

• Springboard

• Carousel

Learn how to use these navigation patterns in Xamarin.Forms and how to 
approach them in Xamarin.Android and Xamarin.iOS. Moving between screens 
also requires passing data between them. Dan will talk about different ways to 
maintain state during navigation. 
You will learn about how to:

• Create navigation to get your user from screen-to-screen

• Create many kinds of menus

• Manage state and passing data between pages

• Combine navigation patterns to form a complete app

About the Speaker 
Dan Hermes 
Xamarin MVP, Xamarin and .NET consultant, author, speaker 
Dan Hermes is a Xamarin MVP, software consultant, and founder of Lexicon Systems, an award-winning Xamarin and .NET consulting firm. Dan helps developers create great mobile apps and helps businesses develop a winning mobile strategy. His firm's recent Xamarin projects include a cross-platform app for Thermo Fisher Scientific which won a W3, a Davey award, and was a finalist for a Xammy award. Dan’s clientele includes dozens of software-building firms such as Fidelity Investments, EDS, and Computerworld Magazine. He speaks at conferences and teaches software development at colleges, developer user groups, and corporate training centers. A contemporary Renaissance man, Dan is also active in the arts. He is a recognized composer, his classical crossover music having aired on National 
Public Radio (NPR). He is an active digital artist, exhibiting his work internationally, and a founding director of Art Technology New England (ATNE).  Dan is the author of a new book entitled Xamarin Mobile Application Development. 

His blog is http://mobilecsharpcafe.com/. Connect with him on Twitter at @danhermes or email him at [masked].  

Lexicon Systems is a Xamarin and .NET software consulting firm with offices in Boston, Massachusetts. They work with tech leaders to evolve their organizations while building reliable, current software. They provide services ranging from .NET technical design and architecture to strategy consulting and best practices. Founded in 1999 by technologist Dan Hermes, they specialize in cross-platform mobile applications built using Xamarin. Lexicon also provides direction on .NET and mobile strategy. 
Contact information 
www.lexiconsystemsinc.com
