results.description:
To be a vegetarian is good for your body and soul! However, to be a well-informed vegetarian is even better. Let’s plan to read together great vegetarian books or watch films and discuss them in a circle of vegetarian friends. Books and films selections will be recommended by a professional librarian.


For our March discussion, we can watch an American documentary film Cowspiracy: The Sustainability Secret (2014) and/or an Australian science fiction film Epsilon (also titled Alien Visitor, 1997). Please pick any one of these great films or both or simply show up to join in for a discussion over a cup of coffee, tea, or a light meal.

About Cowspiracy:


Cowspiracy: The Sustainability Secret is a 2014 American documentary film produced and directed by Kip Andersen and Keegan Kuhn. The film explores the impact of animal agriculture on the environment, and investigates the policies of environmental organizations on this issue.
As eye-opening as Blackfish and as inspiring as An Inconvenient Truth, this shocking yet humorous documentary reveals the absolutely devastating environmental impact large-scale factory farming has on our planet, and offers a path to global sustainability for a growing population.


Cowspiracy won the Audience Choice Award at the 2015 South African Eco Film Festival as well as the Best Foreign Film Award at the 12th annual Festival de films de Portneuf sur l'environnement.


About Epsilon:

Epsilon (also titled Alien Visitor) is a 1997 Australian science fiction film that was directed by Rolf de Heer. The film tells the story of a young female that was sent from the planet Epsilon to judge how humans have managed the planet. She crash lands naked in a desert, but is found by a surveyor who gives her some clothes. She informs the surveyor that other alien races consider humans to be failures that suffer from carelessness and greed. She has the ability to transport herself and the surveyor instantly to any location, and she uses this to demonstrate her point. Eventually the two fall in love.
results.name: Discussion of Cowspiracy and Alien Visitor

results.description:
Hello! This event is a tie in with the regular Manga Club events! We have passed three years of Manga Club meetings, and like the last time we held this event, I think we should appreciate the anime adaptations of past titles we have read. That being said, this time is going to be a bit different. Instead of only watching titles from past Manga Club meetings, we are also going to watch titles that might be picked in the future! Thanks again Steven for letting us use your space to host!

We will vote on episodes from some of the following titles based upon past or future Manga Club selections. If something is not here, it’s because the anime is not officially released, it’s just too over watched to justify, or we can’t get our hands on it. However, just so that no one feels left out, youtube clips of media associated with all the choices or non-choices will be made available between selections. Please read the descriptions below.

Another

The school held a secret that nobody must speak of...Spring, 1998.

Assassination Classroom

A creature who blasted the moon into a crescent shows up at Kunugigaoka Junior High School--and he's giving the students a year to assassinate him!

Durarara!

Mikado Ryugamine is a young man who yearns for the city like no other. At the invitation of his childhood friend, Masaomi Kida, he moves to Ikebukuro, Tokyo and enters school there.

Rurouni Kenshin 

Welcome to the Meiji Era. Japan is a land experiencing times of troubled peace and renewal after a long and bloody civil war. Swords and killing are outlawed, but all is not as well as it would seem. Lurking in the shadows are many survivors of the revolution awaiting their chance for vengeance. Only the former government assassin, Kenshin Himura can keep the peace. Kenshin gives up the life of "Battousai The Man Slayer" and sets off as a lone wanderer. His travels lead to the Kamiya Dojo where he discovers the chance to start life over.

Xxxholic

There is no such thing as coincidence; there is only the inevitable…

Watanuki has been haunted by dark spirits his entire life, a curse flowing through his bloodline preventing peace. When his incessant demons drag him to the ornate door of the Dimensional Witch Yuko, he meets a mystical woman of insight and luxury, quick to help those in a bind…for a fee! One might very well end up paying with their soul! To be free of his visions, Watanuki will work in her shop of dreams and wishes. There is always a price to pay…

Yakitate!! Japan

Kazuma Azuma wants to make bread. Not just any kind of bread though. He wants to make a bread that represents Japan itself and can stand toe-to-toe with rice as a national food. Thanks to his legendary “Hands of the Sun,” unnaturally warm hands that allow dough to ferment faster, Kazuma's bread is like a slice of Heaven. And when the Pantasia Rookie Competition arrives, everyone will get a taste of his skill! Along with his friend Kawachi, he’ll go up against koala karate masters, Harvard bread scientists, samurai with rolling-pin swords and more as he bakes his way to glory!

Directions: Kenmore stop on the green line T. As you exit the station from where you would normally tap your card, take the tunnel on the left side. Once you come up the stairs out into the daylight, the apartment complex is a few minute walk down to your right.

Late arrival: I will e-mail out my number the night before so if you are running late, just call or text to let me know!
results.name: Manga Anime Night 2! Rise of the Future Titles!

results.description:
The final movie in this series...is there any hope for the human race?   Will the divergent be it's savior....or destroyer?


Showtime is at 7.  I will be at the theater about 6.  I will wait outside the ropes near the concession stand until they let us into the inner lobby.  We will head in for seats as soon as they let us.  Please note this is in the downstairs theater....it is IMAX, but not 3D.  

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Plot Summary:

After the earth-shattering revelations of "Insurgent," Tris must escape with Four and go beyond the wall enclosing Chicago. For the first time ever, they will leave the only city and family they have ever known in order to find a peaceful solution for their embroiled city. Once outside, old discoveries are quickly rendered meaningless with the revelation of shocking new truths. Tris and Four must quickly decide who they can trust as a ruthless battle ignites beyond the walls of Chicago which threatens all of humanity. In order to survive, Tris will be forced to make impossible choices about courage, allegiance, sacrifice and love.

Please bring games that you think the group would enjoy playing.

Beef, chicken, turkey "sliders" and veggie burgers will be provided. Since I can't find actual slider patties, they'll be regular patties cut smaller =P There will also be some fries and tater tots (baked). 

Any food and drink you'd like to bring will be appreciated. If you'd like suggestions, here are some ideas: cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, onions, ketchup, mayo, mustard, veggies, salad, and fruits. Please post in the comments so that people can plan accordingly. 

Allergy info:

If you have any allergies or dietary restrictions, please let me know in the popup box when you RSVP.

Location:

Vincent's place is near Porter Square, in Somerville (The address will be sent to attendees.) It is less than a 10-min walk from the Red Line and the 77, 83 and 87 buses stop nearby. Street parking (free) is also available but carpooling is encouraged =)

The next Cape Ann Contra Dance will be Saturday, March 19, at the Magnolia Library Community Center, 1 Lexington Street, Magnolia, MA. The dancing starts at 7:00 PM. No experience is necessary. All dances are taught. Dancers of all ages are welcome; attendees range from eight years to 80 plus years! Everyone has a great time listening and dancing to the live music provided by the Cape Ann Contra Band and Friends. There is a requested donation of $10 per dancer, dancers younger than 16 are free. This event is supported in part by a grant from the Gloucester Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency. The Cape Ann Contra Dances are organized and produced by Folk Life Studio. Drinking water is available. Please bring water bottles to reduce the use of paper cups. Other non-alcoholic drinks and finger food snacks are welcomed to share during the break. For more information,

results.description:
Beware of overlooking the wines of Le Marche!

This mountainous region on the east coast of Central Italy is not well-known beyond its beautiful coastline, but it produces excellent wines. Unquestionably its best are the whites made from Verdicchio, especially those of Matelica. With their tell-tale bitter almond note, these wines are among the finest whites from throughout Italy. Pecorino (not to be confused with the like-named cheese), Passerina and Grechetto are among the other distinctive whites worth seeking out, as we turn the corner into spring.

The best red wines of Le Marche are rich, dark, and powerful, and often bear the DOC names Piceno and Conero, as well as Marche IGT.

Please plan to spend $15-$25, and a few days searching, for a bottle from Le Marche, and bring it in a paper bag, along with four glasses and a food item to share.

Three spots at this tasting will be reserved for first-time hosts who post a new event on the BBWT board before 2/28/16 for a spring or summer date. Once you've done so, post a comment here or send Michael a message, and you will be added to the RSVP list as long as those spots remain.

photo courtesy of BBWT member Karen who is traveling through Le Marche at the time of this posting

results.description:
New Year’s Eve (Sylvester: Tragödie einer Nacht)

Live Musical Accompaniment by Robert Humphreville

Directed by Lupu Pick. With Eugen Klöpfer, Edith Posca, Frida Richard

Germany 1924, 35mm, b/w, silent, 66 min 


This idiosyncratic rarity is the gem of the whole carte blanche as far as I’m concerned! A Kammerspiele, or middle-class chamber drama, Sylvester is the simple story—I think it’s a comedy, but who knows?—of a man beleaguered by tensions between his mother and his wife during the final hours of a single New Year’s Eve. The domestic action unfolds, elegantly eschewing intertitles, with an extremely mannered expressionism that bizarrely slows itself down to near tableau-like immobility at times. The performances, often brisk, can just as often be so slow, and the actors’ poses held so long, as to be exciting, electrifying even! The closer the three strange thespians come to stock-stillness, the more they somehow approach the uninhibited language of dance, and one doesn’t even care if the intended result is comedy or tragedy—it’s somehow both in this oddball ellipses-drunk film. Director Pick is a startling revelation, a true eccentric with a singular filmic voice. This forgotten actor/filmmaker, I aver, was as great as kino immortal F.W. Murnau, his comrade in virtuosic German camera movement, tonal innovation and untimely death—they died separately but four days apart in 1931. What couldn’t they have achieved if granted just another ten years each! Eugen Klöpfer essays the husband role wearing, it seems, the body of someone else, someone that doesn’t quite fit his skin or gait; he is the epitome of bodily and marital discomforts. Edith Posca, Pick’s wife and frequent collaborator, plays the young frau, while Frida Richard takes on the role of the most memorable mother-in-law in film history. Print courtesy Cinémathèque Française.

Followed at 8:30 by The Big House

Directed by George Hill. With Chester Morris, Wallace Beery, Lewis Stone
US 1930, 35mm, b/w, 87 min

This pre-code prison picture—I know, you feel like you’ve already seen every prison picture already, but this one is directed with so much visual assurance, charm and bracing characterization!—is fresh as the day it came out of the lab. The great Frances Marion, longtime writer for Mary Pickford, won the first of her two best-screenplay Oscars for this wonderfully plotted crime melodrama. Coen brothers fetish-object Wallace Beery nabbed the lead role of Butch when the already-signed Lon Chaney came down with his deadly throat cancer—and a loveable superstar was born! But the truly arresting performance of the movie belongs to Robert Montgomery as a cowardly young inmate who just can’t cut the prison code and turns instead to snitching. Montgomery possesses such a vast vocabulary of facial expressions for dread, shame, guilt, fear, skulking, sketchiness, horror and worthless pigeonheartedness that when I first saw The Big House I found myself standing up and pointing with horrified self-identification at this astonishing man’s mug! You’re watching the English language version here, but the film was simultaneously shot in German, French and Spanish versions as well; the German was directed by Pál Fejös and starred Gustav Diessl.


The HFA offers an evening of fun, iconic, historic Cinema with musical accompaniment that occurs just once.  Ever.


Come for one, or both, and a Meetup at Grafton Street Pub that never disappoints.

John
results.how_to_find_us: We can gather at the Grafton Street Pub as early as 5:15 for fuel and discussion of Silent Films with Robert Humphries Musical Accompanment, Pre-Code Prison Films, and upcoming HFA and IFF films
results.name: HARVARD FILM ARCHIVE DOUBLE FEATURE - NEW YEAR'S EVE followed by THE BIG HOUSE

As some of you have heard, our fearless and fun-loving leader Dan Corwin passed away in May.  We are of course quite saddened. 

September 1 Update:

Dan's kids have scattered some of his ashes in the Tennessee Smokey Mountains with family.  They are would like to aim for the spring to hold a bonfire memorial with friends in the Boston area. 

We will wait until they are ready and then look to inform you all.  Therefore the date I'm posting here is just a placeholder.  Please stay tuned!

Best,Peter

results.description:
• Ready to take this practice to the next level?  

• Spiritually, sensually, intimately?  

• Looking to spend more time going deeper with each partner you encounter?

•   Want to learn more about Tantra and take it into your life in a  more profound way so it impacts your life and not just "in workshop?"  

• Are you willing to stop saying "in my real life...." and come to experience complete integration of body/mind, self and One, spirituality and sexuality?  

__________________________________________

The Intimate Puja Circle - Advanced Practice - will offer an opportunity to go deeper into the practice and with your community, if you choose to.  The first half of the evening will be shorter as well, leaving more room for connection during the Puja Circles in the second half of the night!  

Ever wish you had more time???  You asked for it and here it is!  :)  Please keep reading for more important details..... 

______________________________

This Intimate Puja Circle is for those who have been practicing with me for 3 months or longer.  This is event is for intermediate and advanced practitioners and students. 

_______________________________


If you have not worked with me (Robyn) before but have done other workshops on Tantra, relationship and intimacy - there is a short phone interview required so that we can assess whether the Advanced Practice Intimate Puja Circle is best for you.  Please email me privately [masked] so that we can set up a time to talk.  

_______________________________

Even if you've been before, please read the description below in full before RSVPing to this event.   Thank you!   

_______________________________

Please note that this event runs for 3 hours and will be offered on Friday and/or Saturday nights depending on the month 


_______________________________

A Puja, in Sanskrit, means reverence, honor, worship and adoration.  It's used by the Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, and others -- as a ceremony to honor a very special occasion; it's also used more often as part of a sacred ritual - a practice to support opening to the wisdom of the Divine -- your Source. 

Intimate Puja Circle - Advanced Practice, will be a place to: 

• Share a deeper and sacred connection with the Intimate Puja community

• Learn and practice Tantra, yoga, meditation and other tools and techniques for expansion, awakening and living a joyful, peaceful, abundant life 

• Practice authentic relating with one another; take risks, make choices, honor your boundaries 

• Experience deep connections with those interested in sacred sexuality, energy, expanded orgasm, conscious relationship, spirituality  - people like YOU!

Tantra For Everyone:  

This special evening will begin with many invitations to connect with each other in light and playful ways -- always with the opportunity to go as deep as you choose.  Single or coupled, you'll experience Tantra as a way to say 'hello', get to know one another, mingle and connect.

The Advanced Practice Intimate Puja Circle will offer an opportunity to go deeper if you choose to.  And the first half of the evening will be shorter, leaving more room for connection during the Puja Circles in the second half of the night!  

Here's what Participants are saying!

"This is a very special event; a non-threatening, yet deep and authentic way to meet others. I've been online dating for years and it's just not for me.  I've met some really special people at your events."

"Saved my marriage, literally."  

"Congratulations and thank you for a wonderful evening.  Reflecting on it today, I am just amazed at the intimacy I experienced with virtually no history and the joy I received."

"Very different from my normal way of life, you did create on a small scale  and it was exactly what I was hoping for....the experience of deeper intimacy."

"It's so amazing to walk into a room of "strangers" and walk out feeling in love with everyone!"

"I didn't think I'd be able to connect with anyone there.  I was so surprised, and delighted, how easy it was to enjoy myself with every man in that room! Thank you Robyn, for your excellent facilitation skills. I felt totally safe!"

"We have to wait a whole month until the next one????"

"We love to come as a couple and meet others on a similar path."


The Intimate Puja Circle</a><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=SHVW639WM28LC"><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=ZES8HVDSP97PA"></a> itself will begin part-way through the night during which you'll have the chance to connect more deeply with others (one-on-one) -- this part of the evening will be facilitated, with a structure offered, however, you will have ample time to co-create with the beloved in front of you!!  You will be at choice and encouraged to ask for 100% of what you want.


Deepen With Your Community:

Once the formal part of the evening is over, there'll be time to dance, hang out, cuddle, snuggle, relax, process, and rest.  There will always be chocolate! 

The Intimate Puja Circle community is growing and growing!  There are hundreds of men, women and couples who have been participating for the past 2 1/2 years.  About 50 - 75% of the monthly gatherings are "regulars" -- spiritual-minded beings who are committed to coming back to love with themselves, God and each other. People's whose lives have changed significantly because of this practice.  

"I have been on a wonderful journey of “Coming back to Love” of self, my children and those that come in my path each day. “Coming back to Mitchell” is synonymous with where I am and how much grateful I am for allowing myself the ability to re-open my heart and soul to those that wish to receive my Shiva and Shakti within me. Instrumental in my shift comes from meeting and integrating the practices of Robyn Vogel, psychotherapist, Intimacy and Sex Coach, and facilitator of “middle-path” Tantra, teaching me Tantra and how being present allows the miracle of conscious living." 

 -- Mitchell Rosenwald / Realtor


Questions You May Have:

Please email me to set up a time to talk if you are unsure whether this Advanced Practice Intimate Puja is for you or not.  [masked]
results.name: SOLD OUT Intimate Puja Circle -  Advanced Practice

results.description:
Guests are transported into a real-world gaming environment; an experience we call Questing. Teams of 3-5 guests literally move through our Quests tackling a variety of mental and physical challenges. Success in the first challenge means entry into the next challenge and so on… Failure in any challenge means starting over or selecting another Quest.

No video games, no virtual reality, no special clothing or equipment....real people, real Questing, real adrenaline and heart-pumping excitment.
results.name: BODA BORG!!!!!

results.description:
This meetup will conclude our  winter program with an indoor photo shoot. We will be creating refractographs, a very unique and colorful way of creating intricate light abstracts.


Please make sure to read the entire description in a regular browser, not the mobile app, which doesn't show the images. 

This event is for paid members only.


Refractorgraphs, as the name suggests, are abstract patterns created by white light breaking on a transparent surface. In some cases, the white light is also diffracted and breaks into its individual colors through the glassy object. What works really well is simply using the bottom of a wine glass, but shiny surfaces such as CDs, Mylar, glass rods and prisms will work, too. This is all about experimenting and you are guaranteed to walk away with some unique creations.

This is an indoor photo shoot to combat the cold outside, no need to dress too warmly.


Here is what you need to bring:

• Your camera body with a body cap. No need for a lens, you will be shooting without a lens, so there is no f-stop. Only ISO and exposure time.


• At least one flashlight (charge the battery or bring spares!). Does not have to be overly bright.

• Gaffers tape, if you have it. Clips may work, too. Don't use duct tape, it leaves residues.


• At least two, better three tripods, if you have them. One with ball head holding your camera, another one holding the flashlight, but that can be any cheap kind of stand, even home-made. They can all be very small and the gorilla pod, if you have one, is great to hold your flashlight. This is also a great "tripod" for photo shoots on observation platforms, such as the Empire State Building (which does not allow regular tall tripods). You will need to add a ball head to this, I recommend the affordable SunwayFoto pan ball head, a good compromise between load, quality and cost. Also great to keep a second tripod for your second camera on expensive trips.


• Instead of a third tripod, this flexible arm (Plamp II PP-200) is a great and affordable solution to hold the refracting object in front of the camera, this is what you need to move most often, after your camera.


• Some sort of refracting object. Bring a cheap, sturdy wine glass (the stem is easier to clamp than a water glass, and the stem may act refracting, too). Prisms, specialty glass or shiny surfaces, a CD (preferably blank). Keep it small, 2-3 inches tops.


• Color gels to color your refractographs. This swatch book here has several hundred different gels in it with information on the density and color and you can use these also for flash coloring or for coloring your flashlights for our light painting events. 

• If you need it, a flashlight, such as those we use for astro-landscape photography. We will be operating in a dark room, but there will be some light from the pin-hole flashlights. Any bright light will ruin everyone else's shot! These two solutions are my favorites and they will last a long time and can be used on all our night photo shoots. The Celestron dimmable astronomers light and the much smaller LRI FMR Photon Freedom LED Keychain Micro-Light, my personal favorite. 


What we will have onsite:

• Tables all ready for to set up your own station: Tripod set to low for the camera, another tripod or stand for the flashlight and a clamp or 3rd stand for the refracting object. If you have tall tripods and a clamp, you can also set up on the floor.


• Pin-hole covers for your flashlight (they will be taped to your light).


• Some tape, but it helps if you bring some, too.


• Some refracting objects (not enough for everyone).

• Some color gels

• A few additional stands, but please try to bring your own.


Here is an instructional video on how to do refractograms. Please make sure to watch this before you come to this event!

And here is another page with information

This is the recommended setup:

Tripod with camera, no lens. Clamp (or second tripod) which holds the refracting object (a wine glass here). A Third tripod, here a gorilla pod, to hold the flashlight (taped on it). If you use a tripod to hold the glass, a ballhead is strongly recommended. Other contraptions may be used to replace tripods, but we will mostly set up on tables.


This is how it looks when the light hits the glass, you can see how the light is reflected into the camera opening.


This is how we will operate: in the dark with only a small light shining around. The entire room needs to be kept dark to do this. Anyone who needs a bathroom break needs to let others know and wait until exposures are done.


The first image at the top shows a plain refractograph from the bottom of a wine glass, only minor color is visible.

The second image was created by using a CD as the reflective surface and the colors are created by the CD

The third image below is similar to the first, but I was using two colors gels, a blue and a red to color the pattern.
results.name: Indoor shoot: Refractographs

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court. There are two individual bathrooms that some people change in. Some people come prepared to play, while others change.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers/Karaoke nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Be sure to bring socks with you in order to play and no $20 bills please!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58

results.description:
Here we go people, it would be an understatement to say that Chez has been a huge musical influence to us through the years. There is not much to say other than he is one of artists who we respect the most in the entire game. His productions are classic and his djing is sublime. We know you will enjoy

Chez Damier (Balance Alliance, Prescription Records KMS, Chicago)

with support from Matt Mcneill and Chad Spigner

Here is some more about Chez

Already a legendary figure in electronic music, Chez Damier has played close witness to many of the pivotal moments in the history of house and techno. Jointly responsible with studio partner Ron Trent for both Prescription Records - widely recognised as one of the greatest house labels of all time - and ‘The Morning Factory’ - one of the most ethereal jams ever to rock a room - Chez Damier is a true deep house pioneer. More than that, the Chicago DJ has played pivotal roles in the development of KMS, The Music Institute and The Bellville Three, hallowed pieces of musical history that prove his contribution to dance music over the years. As an artist Chez Damier represents a unique blend; he is as impetuous and daring as now as in 1989 and being able to qualify this with his own unique heritage makes his releases and DJ performances doubly formidable. Today his sets are entirely unique, not just because of the experience and knowledge he can call upon. After something of a hiatus, a series of releases for the German label Mojuba signalled that he was on his way back to show the new artists the way and nowadays he has taken the torch of Prescription by launching Balance Alliance as a home for some of the most forward thinking and talented producers of the next generation to join him on the imprint. Studio partnerships with Parisian Ben Vedren has reignited the production flame under several alias, and so now he is back making his best work once more. A regular around the world from DC10 in Ibiza to Smart Bar Chicago and many more, Chez Damier is a modern house hero.


$10 all night
party by CSC
flier by Alfredo
visuals by Jon Von Bonk
Facebook Event Page
https://www.facebook.com/events/805905842870069/

results.description:
ABOUT MEATOUT

Since 1985, thousands around the world have celebrated the first day of Spring by eating vegan for the day in a huge international event called Meatout. 
Each year, 
Meatout raises awareness of the benefits of eating vegan: 
* helping animals (we don't see what we don't harm!), 
* achieving greater health (for those on plant-based diets), 
* saving the planet (global benefit), and 
* reducing economic injustices that are associated with meat production and throughout the meat industry (global benefit).

Are you excited yet? Read on. 
Or go ahead and take the pledge to give it a try!

What can a plant-based diet do for the world?

By pledging to eat vegan, you’ll be sparing countless animals and saving the planet. 

http://www.meatout.org/#sp-meatout-wrapper

http://www.meatout.org

Everywhere, every year!  Since 1985!
results.name: GREAT AMERICAN MEATOUT - Everywhere, every year!  Since 1985!

results.description:
Organizers: Ashley Carneal[masked], Joe Ciarcia -[masked] (note: coverage at the trail head is terrible, if you call, also send a text but keep in mind that we may not even be able to receive texts at this trailhead)


How to sign up for the WAITING LIST:
1. DO NOT USE A MOBILE DEVICE
2. RSVP yes
3. **** ANSWER ALL 6 RSVP QUESTIONS ****
4. Verify you've answers the RSVP questions by going back to the hike listing, click on "change RSVP", leave it set to "yes", click "OK", and you should see the answers to your questions, if not, answer them (there are 3 pages of questions (2 per page) and a button you must press after the 3rd page to confirm).
5. If you did not answer the RSVP questions, you will not be considered for this hike.
6. Make sure your Meetup settings allow you to receive email from the organizers, and make sure you actually CHECK that email address.

I will periodically review RSVP responses and add those who have answered all of the questions thoroughly and meet the requirements for this hike.

=========================

What We're Doing...

Join Ashley and Joe for a hike up Mt. Isolation. This is one of the few hikes in the Whites where we will hike to a higher elevation in order to grab a summit at a lower elevation and then ascend again in order to descend. While I usually prefer to avoid out and back routes if possible, the out and back on this hike is a rare gem as you get spectacular views going both to and from Isolation. This hike is rated as ADVANCED due to terrain, elevation gain, and distance.


NH4K - Mt. Isolation @ 4003 feet

Distance:           13.34 miles
Book Time:         9 hrs 23 minutes*
Vertical Gain:   5,471 ft
Projected pace: ~1.5 to ~2.0 MPH


* Book time does not account for snack breaks, pee breaks, scenery gawking, photo ops, silly walks, or alien abductions. It is provided as a reference only. DO NOT MAKE PLANS FOR THE EVENING with the assumption you will actually make it there on time.


Guests are not permitted. All participants are screened to ensure group safety, and to make sure everyone enjoys the hike.


Dogs are not permitted (unless they're named Kali and have completed the grid)

What to Bring...


Light traction (Hillsounds or Kahtoola Microspikes, no substitutions) and 10 point (or more) crampons required (throw the snowshoes in the car, we'll make a decision at the trailhead).

While it's the first day of spring, "seasons" don't apply to the White Mountains so, you'll need a full winter pack for this hike. Make sure you have a headlamp with fresh batteries as our more civilized start time may have us finishing in the dark. Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike (no cotton ever!):

http://hbbostonamc.org/docs/Gear_lists/Winter_Dayhike_equip.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

You need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety. Overestimating your abilities may put others at severe risk. 

Weather...

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use this link for the current weather forecast:


http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.2147877750005&lon=-71.30923773199964#.VubFVITMz8s

Directions...


Travel time from Boston: Typically 3 hour to 3 hours 10 minutes (pad that with some more time to account for coffee stops, etc.)
Meeting Place: Pinkham Notch/AMC Joe Dodge Lodge  
Time: 9:00 AM
Lat/Lon:[masked],[masked] (enter in to GPS or copy and paste into Google Maps App)


Use this link for customizable driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/B2pKYtii8y52

Carpools


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: NH4K - Isolation via Glenn Boulder (ADVANCED)

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked] 


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

This is rescheduled from the polar vortex in February - it will NOT cont for "winter" since it will be the first day of spring but it's still a fun trip  

The plan is to hike to two 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Hancock and South Hancock. We will use Hancock Notch Trail, Cedar Brook Trail, and Hancock Loop Trail to go counter-clockwise, hitting (steep ascent) South Hancock first, then Hancock. We will then return using the same trails.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people because we will be traveling within designated wildness protection areas.

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 9.8 miles and climb about 2,900 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/21-Mt-Hancock-4420--26-South-Hancock-4319

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.0837&lon=-71.4937#.Vpcr-TblweI


=== What to Bring ===


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Hancock Overlook parking lot which is just east of the hairpin turn on Route 112 east of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 140 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 15 minutes to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/pQW9Xtmbo4B2

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.name: NH4K ... Hancock and South Hancock (INTERMEDIATE)

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The hike is at 9. Please be prompt, we leave on time.  


Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

results.description:
Poses begin the first Sunday of the month unless otherwise noted.

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $70.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
The Secret to great wedding photography

Spring is in the air and wedding season will soon be upon us. Are you as ready as you can be to handle the organization and execution of a successful and stress free event? 

As a veteran wedding photographer I have experienced just about everything a wedding can throw at you and over the years I have developed an approach that helps me to avoid the major pitfalls - leaving me free to focus my attention on photographing the happy couple. 

In this one day session I will share my approach with you. I'll walk you through each of the separate stages of a successful wedding photography engagement, by breaking it down into actions you should consider at key times in the process. 

• Finding and booking clients

• Long before the day

• Shortly before the day

• On the day

• Shortly after the day 

• Long after the day

You will walk away from the session with a complete check-list that will take you step by step through the wedding photography process from beginning to end. 

From finding a client to selling the finished photographs; from hiring assistants to getting paid; from equipment choices to legal issues this workshop will cover it all. 

•
results.name: Get ready for wedding season!

results.description:
ALL ONE-DAY WORKSHOPS INCLUDE A PIZZA LUNCH

Wicked Fun CareOne Lex RunThe 2016 Wicked Fun CareOne Lex Run 5K Run/Walk will be held Sunday March 20th, 2016 starting at 10:00 a.m. in Lexington, MA at CareOne Lexington, 178 Lowell Street, Lexington MA.  A portion of the proceeds from this race will benefit Breast Cancer Awareness Foundation. 

Runners and walkers welcome -- tell your friends and bring the kids! Post-race party will be held at CareOne Lexington, 178 Lowell Street, Lexington MA immediately following the award ceremony. Please come and help us celebrate the first of what we hope will be an annual run! Food, raffles and fun!! 


CourseThe event will begin at 10:00 a.m. Race will be starting and finishing at CareOne Lexington, 178 Lowell Street, Lexington, MA. The course is a fairly flat 3.1 miles (5K). The course is paved, therefore strollers or baby joggers are allowed on the course. In addition for safety purposes no skateboards, roller blades/skates, bicycles, or animals can be taken on the course. Also note, this race will officially end at 11:30 a.m. therefore, anyone that is not finished at that time will need to follow traffic rules and regulations. Police officers will be done directing traffic after 11:30am. 

Chip timing provided by RaceWire. Top male (s) and female (s) finishers in each age group TBD at time of race

results.description:
Hi all, 

Due to health-related and other material issues, and much to my regret, I am unable to participate in this 1st annual CMF Boating Party. This is in conjunction (also) with my having been invited to participate in two conferences at Harvard in the next two weeks. 

Both conferences are listed as CMF events. The first is the "Just Food?" conference at the Law School on the 25th/26th (link HERE), and the second is "Spirit of Sustainable Agriculture" conference at the Divinity School (March 31st-April 1st - link HERE). 

I would simply be asking too much of myself to actually "Organize" and fully participate in the Boating Party event, especially as I am now a two-hour commute from Cambridge. 

So, in short, you're all on your own for this one. I hope to do better next year. 

Should anyone else be interested in stepping up as organizer, normal CMF protocols apply in that you can just post your plans below (on the message board) and see what happens. 

Steve

:: :: ::

The First Annual CMF Boating Party, to be held on the first day of spring, in celebration of life ... (and with a nod of gratitude to Pierre-Auguste Renoir and all artists who depict a richness of life in their works). 

This event will include a few hours on the water, followed by a few hours of dining and socializing. Details to be determined. 

The Luncheon of the Boating Party (Le déjeuner des canotiers - 1881) is a painting by French impressionist Pierre-Auguste Renoir, now in The Phillips Collection museum in Washington, D.C. It depicts a group of Renoir's friends relaxing on a balcony at the Maison Fournaise along the Seine river in Chatou, France. 


The painting above has been modified (with apologies to the art-world), by this group's organizer, to represent the mix of people, ranging from the top-hatted, formally-dressed folks in the background, to the more casually outfitted fellows in the foreground (in boating attire), who sometimes find themselves brought together by a common interest, as is often the case in Cambridge. The focus of the CMF however (as in the painting), is on the latter. 

:: :: ::

Please dress appropriately (top-hat or muscle-shirt ... either way, or both, as you wish).
results.name: A Boating Party

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs


Reality is known through reason


Meaning comes from making a difference


Human hands solve human problems


Be accepting, and be accepted

Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.

results.description:
Join us for a winter hike/snowshoe at Harold Parker State Forest. 

Distance and Terrain: The loop is 4.5 miles and has a moderately diverse terrain. We will be hiking the Southeastern area of the park, including circling the beautiful Salem Pond.
Recommended: Waterproof footwear, hiking boots preferred. Dress in layers because although we might start out chilled, we will definitely warm up! Water, of course, and an easy snack such as trail mix or granola bar that can be eaten while hiking.
Parking: At the intersection of Jenkins Road and Harold Parker Road.
results.how_to_find_us: From I93 take exit 41 onto Route 125 toward Andover/N Andover turn right onto Gould Rd and continue straight onto Harold Parker Rd. The Trailhead parking is at the intersection of Harold Parker Rd. and Jenkins Rd.

results.description:
Rescheduled from 1/19 and 2/13:


Join the BSOT as we make out first trek to Myles Standish State Forest in Carver, MA.

Expect a 8-9 mile trek that will take 5+ hours.  This trek is rated as Easy for terrain and elevation gain of a few hundred feet.   Difficulty ratings are based on elevation gain.  Factor in your own ability to hike 8-9 miles.


Check out 'Difficulty Ratings' at:

http://www.hikenewengland.com/LegendRating.html


RSVPs open on Saturday, March 5.

Carpooling is welcome.  If you would like to carpool you're welcome to post that request in the *Comments* section of this event's page.  But please respond to those posts via *Meetup Messenger*.  You do that by clicking on a member's profile, then clicking on *message*.


http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-south/myles-standish-state-forest.html

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myles_Standish_State_Forest


http://www.friendsmssf.com


Cell Phones and Electronic Devices:

I ask that while on the BSOT events that I host you limit your use of electronic devices to the following activities:

Map My Hike or other Hiking Apps
Location Services
Cameras
Weather Apps

One of the pleasant features of being out and about is that we all get away from the constant distractions of cell phones.  I ask that while on the events I host you:

Don't use your phone (of course! I make exceptions for emergencies and calling a taxi/Uber if you can't make it back on foot!)

Don't listen to the radio.

Don't play music.

Thank you in advance for respecting this request.

The Fine Print: 

No dogs or guests are allowed on BSOT hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events.

Duration: Approximately 5+ hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated Easy.  You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace of 2+ mph. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree (woof!). If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: 

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.
results.name: Myles Standish State Forest

results.description:
Every Sunday at 10:30 AM we gather in our Sunday Circle, a time for gratitude,  prayer, song, and reflection.  Anyone is welcome to simply come as you are to any of these gatherings.  Please join us if you are seeking a time of centering, transformation, and connection with other people on their spiritual journeys. 

In the Sunday Circles we embody a rootedness in a Christian faith that is open to all faiths.  Our minister, Rev. Dr. Ian Mevorach, often preaches a dialogue sermon that invites the insights and wisdom of all who are gathered.   Other ministers, members of the community, or special guests also take turns leading our circles. Themes of spirituality, social and environmental justice, openness and love are at the core. We often engage in interfaith dialogue. We discuss scriptures from the Bible and other sacred texts, as well as explore poetry, music, and other sources of inspiration.  Every first Sunday of the month we celebrate an inclusive communion that is open to all.

Ou Sunday Circles are a time and place where people come together in a sacred way and where various threads in our community are often woven together into a greater whole.
results.how_to_find_us: Our building is located on Common Street overlooking the town green in Natick Center.  Parking in side and back lots.

results.description: Let's hike the Breakheart Reservation in Saugus and Wakefield Mass. The hike will take us an estimated two hours and will follow the perimeters of both ponds (Pearce Lake and Silver Lake) providing scenic water views and beautiful panoramas.   There are many spots ideal for photo opportunities, water breaks, and there are numerous cut off points which can take you back to the main road if need be.  Terrain is varied and will consist of trails with raised roots,  rocks, and muddy areas in which hiking boots with good traction and support will be needed.  If there is interest, participants can enjoy lunch together afterward at a restaurant on nearby Route 1 (most likely Polcari's).  There is plenty of parking by the Vo Tech School on the wooded side of the lot.  We will meet by the large metal gate at the entrance of the park.
results.name: Hiking the trails of the Breakheart Reservation

What to expect: This monthly meeting typically begins with an introduction all around for the benefit of any first-time attendees, and discussion of any announcements, upcoming events, etc. We then move on to a topic of interest to atheists (usually) chosen beforehand. Sometimes participants bring print-outs of articles, research, or books to share on the topic, and sometimes people just come with a story or opinion to share.

We loosely moderate the topical discussion to give everyone a chance to participate. Then the conversation often flows onto other related subjects, sometimes in smaller conversation groups around the table.

If you have any ideas for meeting topics, please let any of the co-organizers know. We can also add announcements or "mini-topics" on the agenda if there's anything you'd like to share with the group.

Sunday Brunch Buffet $18 (Includes Coffee) Plus tax and tip

Other drinks are additional


http://taverninthesquare.com/brunch


Join us at participating restaurants for our award-winning brunch buffet! We offer a rotating selection of items including:


• Chef’s Omellette
• Seasonal Fruits
• Chef’s Carving Station
• Salads
• Lunch Specialties
• Build your own desserts


Tavern in the Square began when a group of friends, with various back rounds in the restaurant industry came together and decided that Boston needed more than a “typical” sports bar. Joey Arcari, an Irish immigrant, came to Boston after gaining work experience in various bars throughout New York City. Renato Valentin began his restaurant work experience as a dishwasher and worked his way up to a chef, and then manager, before joining the partnership. Mark Morris began his restaurant career after many years of being the lead singer of the “Catunes”, one of New England’s most popular bands. Finally, Somerville native, Stephen DeSousa, who found his passion for the industry at age 18 and worked in various restaurants throughout Boston, rounded out the team that created Tavern in the Square.

Join SVT and the Ashland Town Forest Committee to explore the history and nature between Ashland and Framingham. The Ashland Town Forest / Cowassock Woods area has a natural “wealth’’ of granite outcroppings, upland and lowland swamp, vernal pools, mixed hardwood forest, several open pit quarries, and a former high-bush blueberry farm.  Sixty to eighty year old mixed hardwood forests – mixed oak and oak/hickory forest types - are the dominant natural communities that we will see on this walk. 

RSVP for meeting location.

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$2/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $15/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.

Why this spot?

Stumbled across this little nugget on Somerville Beat. Has great reviews on Yelp. Weather permitting, they have outside seating too! It's run by a local family called Borges. And I am all about helping local businesses march ahead. 

What are my brunch options?

They serve Crab Benedict and Nutella banana crepes, umm yum!

Wait, what happened to the Ball Square Cafe?

Ahh! I know folks wanted to visit the Ball Square Cafe last time. But they don't take reservations, and I don't want you all hungry folks to wait for long, like the last time. Next time, eh? 

The usuals:

Singles That Brunch website

Facebook Community page

The Neighborhood website

Brunch P.S: 

It'd be great if you can rsvp only if you can make it. Ok, at least 80% sure. I know plans change, so I encourage you to be prompt about changing your rsvp. 

Why So? So that I can book a table before hand, you guys don't have to wait in line, and others get a chance to explore this spot, if you can't make it.
results.how_to_find_us: 25 Bow St. Somerville MA
results.name: Brunch at 'The Neighborhood'

results.description:
Our Small Doggy PlayDate on Sunday, March 20 will include a Small Doggy Rummage Swap. Many of us have small doggy clothes, sweaters, harnesses, toys, and supplies that our small ones have outgrown or simply will not use. Gather it up and bring your small doggy "stuff" to the PlayDate to freely offer or swap.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Small Doggy Playdates is conveniently held at The Meadows Pet Resort and Spa in Holliston, 140 Summer Street. We meet mostly every 3rd Sunday of the month, 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm.


The Meadows is a multi-million dollar pet resort. The resort provides us with a large, clean indoor room with windows, chairs, water bowls, and plenty of room for our small dogs to play and socialize. Your dog can run around and play with others, off leash, in a safe environment.  

• All small and toy breeds are welcome. We look forward to having owners of FRIENDLY, EASY-GOING small dogs (under 20 lbs), with GOOD DOGGY MANNERS come play and make new friends. Please be sure your small dog(s) is healthy, clean, spayed or neutered, flea-free, and up-to-date with shots. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Feel free to bring a small ball or a special toy for the dogs to play with.


• Due to the increase in participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• To be sure there is enough seating, feel free to bring your own folding chair. 

• Due to some food allergy-prone dogs, please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.
results.name: Small Doggy PlayDate & RUMMAGE SWAP - RSVP for Sunday, March 20, 1:00-2:30 p.m.

results.description:
Join us at the Drumlin Farm Wildlife Sanctuary where you can experience the winter landscape and a working farm in one location!

Come prepared to spend a few hours outdoors exploring the sites and settings of this unique location. We will begin with a short class session to cover the techniques of shooting the winter landscape (class handout included) and then we will move on to a field shooting experience. 

Drumlin Farm is owned and operated by the Mass Audubon features 200 acres of mixed landscape and 4 miles of trails. The farm and fields offer a mix of structures and forms along with plenty of  critters to photograph.

It's proximity to Boston and variety of terrain make this a great location for photo exploration.

Grab you boots, pack your tripod and join us for a fun winter photo experience.

PLEASE NOTE: Mass Audubon charges an admission fee (rates vary) which you will have to pay open entry.  That cost is reflected in the lowered cost for thsi class.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Map Link:   https://goo.gl/maps/zMUs9rvSF7n
results.name: WINTER LANDSCAPE  (and critters) WORKSHOP

results.description:
This group will be for exploring the methods of growing and propagating mushrooms as well as trying to simplify methods and develop new ones. Open, because all methods developed by this group will become public domain. Mushrooms are critical to the health of the worlds ecosystems and farmland, 95% of all plants form synbiotic relationships with fungi and plants first relied upon this relationship to colonize the land, discovered by way of fossils. We can help ourselves in many ways by utilizing the many unique attributes of fungi for food and healing of our lands.

Our inspiration comes from dedicated mycologists like Paul Stamets and Tradd Cotter.

This is a regular monthly group meetup.
results.name: Open Mycology Group

results.description:
We skip past all the Witch-related hokum to visit: the former Salem jail (the oldest continuously operating jail in America); the former Salem courthouse (the oldest continuously operating courthouse in America); Salem City Hall (the oldest continually operating city hall in America); [Salem doesn't update readily]; the Ropes 'Spinster' Gardens; the witch hanging site on Proctor's Ledge; the start site of the Great Salem Fire (also at Proctor's Ledge, a historical coincidence rarely noted); the Giles Corey 'pressing' site; historical homes in the McIntire District, not just the mansions but the smaller gems on the adorable side streets; the site of the recent cobblestone controversy near the Cinnamon House hullabaloo; the smallest listed street (too narrow even for bicycles); Artsy-Craftsy Front St; the Seven Gables house (natch); the whimsical outdoor sculptures of Ferry Wharf; and more.

Tour begins and ends in the waiting room of the new Salem Depot, accessible to rail, car, bus and bike. Total distance walked will be about 3 miles, and Proctor's Ledge will be muddy, so wear comfy shoes.

Attendance is limited to 50, so if you're unable to attend please unreserve and open a spot for someone on the waiting list.
results.name: Walk Salem - What the Tourists Don't See

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Curious about how Data Science works? Well, it's a vast field, we can't cover it all, but we'll talk a bit about what statistics is, why everyone cares about at least a few statistics, why most people hate statistics in general, and why Bayesian statistics is less painful.  Then we'll work through this tutorial by Quantopian's Thomas Wiecki on Bayesian MCMC sampling, which describes how the Metropolis algorithm works to draw approximate samples from the posterior distribution.

Please see this page for details about finding us.  (Note that the room has changed since this meetup was first posted.  56-180 is the planned meeting room,[masked] is now a backup location.  They're just down the hall from each other, anyway.)

It's not necessary and we will not devote any time to it at the meetup, but you might find it fun to install iPython and load up the notebook on your own laptop.
results.name: Introduction to Bayesian statistics

results.description:
All are welcome to join the members of the Wampum Chapter of the NCTA as we wear our green for the annual St. Patrick’s Day Hike at CEMEX, east of the Beaver River.  Meet at the Wampum Community Park and Train Station at the south end of town at 1:00 PM.  We’ll shuttle up to our starting point on Snake Run Road and hike 3 miles on the North Country National Scenic Trail down to the Bevington Boat Launch on the river.  The views of the PA countryside are expansive this time of the year as we trek along through the woods and fields of the CEMEX property.

Hot dogs, pot luck, and socializing are on tap at the Train Station at the conclusion of this walk!  Bring something to share, or just bring yourself.  If you don't want to do the three-mile walk, you're still welcome to come out that afternoon to the train station to check out this great community asset that the Wampum Revitalization Committee has developed.

Dress for the weather, bring along drinking water and a snack (if you'd like).  This hike is rated as moderate in difficulty as the weather can be iffy in mid March and there are some short climbs and descents along the way.
results.how_to_find_us: The revitalized train station is on Main St. in Wampum, just to the south of the bridge over the Beaver River.
results.name: Wampum Chapter Annual St. Patrick's Day Hike Hot Dog Roast Pot Luck

results.description:
We want to make our services available to everyone. Some can’t spare the time for one of our standard appointments, or can’t afford even our low-cost/pay-what-you-can consultation option. Recognizing this, we will offer short, focused mini-consultations, including one herbal preparation, for free to all comers. This is your opportunity to talk with a practicing herbalist, share any health concerns you may have, and receive personalized education in the preparation and use of herbs.

Herbal Free Clinic - March 20th 2016

Sunday, March 20th, 2016
1:00pm – 5:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The consultation and one preparation are free. (Donations are accepted.)

For this free clinic day, we cannot schedule specific individual appointment times – everything will be first come, first served. If we have a high turnout this may entail some wait time. We expect the mini-consultations themselves to run approximately 20 minutes each, plus 5-10 minutes for preparation of herbs.

Please spread the word! We would especially like to reach out to underserved individuals who would not otherwise have access to herbal medicine.

Please note: this is not a medical clinic: we are not doctors, we are not dispensing medical advice, and we are not diagnosing or treating any medical conditions. We are providing information and education from the perspective of traditional herbalism. The herbal preparations we provide are to be considered samples to aid in your personal investigation into the effects of herbs in your own body.

If you plan to come by, it helps us if you RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Free Herbal Clinic Day

venue.name: Kurukulla Center for Tibetan Buddhist Studies

results.description:
Kurukulla Center is once again delighted to have Venerable Amy Miller Visit our Center for teachings this coming March

Venerable Amy will be arriving on Friday, March 18, and will depart on Friday, March 26. Her teaching schedule is as follows:

Saturday, March 19, 10:00 am to 5:00 pm:

Awakening Mindfulness: The Importance of Meditation and How to Practice Calm Abiding (Shiné)

Sunday, March 20, 1:00 to 5:00 pm:

Get Real: The Wisdom Realizing Emptiness and How It Creates a Happier, More Peaceful Life

Tuesday, March 22, 7:00 to 9:00 pm:

The Truth about Tantra: Breaking through the Myth and Understanding Initiations, Sadhanas, and How it Shortcuts Our Path to Enlightenment

Thursday, March 24, 7:00 to 9:00 pm:

Transforming Anger and Depression

Detailed information regarding each of these classes will shortly be published in our Calendar

About Venerable Amy:

Venerable Amy J. Miller (Ven. Lobsang Chodren) was ordained as a Buddhist nun in June 2000 by the great Tibetan master, Ven. Choden Rinpoche, and has been teaching extensively since 1992. She first encountered Tibetan Buddhism in the spring of 1987 during a course at Kopan Monastery in Nepal. Since then, she has spent a great deal of time engaged in meditation retreats, study, teaching, and Buddhist center management throughout the world.

Her teaching style emphasizes a practical approach to integrating Buddhist philosophy into everyday life. She is happy to help people connect with meditation and mindfulness in an effort to gain a refreshing perspective on normally stressful living. Amy’s courses and retreats focus on establishing and maintaining a meditation and mindfulness practice, death and dying, overcoming anxiety and depression, battling addiction, dealing with self-esteem issues, and cultivating compassion and loving kindness. She is also often involved in leading a variety of retreats.

Amy is the co-author of Buddhism in a Nutshell - and a contributor to Living in the Path, a series of on-line courses produced by FPMT. Based in the United States, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Amy teaches and leads retreats and pilgrimages around the world. Her teaching schedule and other information can be found at www.AmyMiller.com.www.AmyMiller.com
results.name: Get Real: The Wisdom Realizing Emptiness and How It Creates a Happier Life
