results.description:
Greetings Boston Node.JS & Javascript Community!

Thanks to all of you that attended the February meetup this past Thursday - we had an amazing showing, one of the highest turnouts yet!  I will be posting more pictures from that meetup soon, as well as the slides from the other speakers.

In the spirit of continuing our monthly meetings, I am announcing the March meetup to be held on the 22nd of March at a new location - Fitbit's Boston HQ at 1 Marina Park Drive (7th Floor).  Fitbit will be providing pizza and beer for all attendees.

We have a GREAT lineup of speakers for this next event, check out the details below and let me know if you have any questions or feedback. I hope to see you all in March!

Brian

-------------

Rohit Kumar & Rajul Kumar

AWS Lambda

Recently Amazon came up with a brilliant new service which allows to run your code in cloud environment without worrying about infrastructure and with minimal costs, yes we are talking about "AWS Lambda service". Although it was recently launched, it has gained a lot of traction. Why is it gaining popularity? What parts of an application can make the best use of it? Why is Auto-scaling, high-availability, out of box deployment, pay-per-use are usually the terms associated with AWS.

Join us for an evening where we discuss answers to the above questions and some realistic problems we faced while developing a similar service.

Bios: 

Rohit Kumar - Pursuing Masters in Computer Science at Northeastern University. Developing a compute service similar to  "AWS lambda"  for Massachusetts Open Cloud using Openstack. After working for 3 years developing softwares I decided to move to Boston for Masters degree. Find interest in Virtualization, machine learning. Javascript is my another love.

Rajul Kumar - Masters in Computer Science at Northeastern University. Currently developing a service similar to AWS Lambda for MOC using OpenStack. Before this, was working in business process automation and system integration and developing solutions. Find interest in PAAS solutions. Like to implement in Java and Python. Learning Javascript as a new gateway.

James Sturtevant


Vorlon.Js - Debugging in a Multidevice World

Wouldn't it be nice to never again have to ask the question, "What browser are you using"?  With Vorlon.JS, an open source, platform agnostic tool, your ability to be a multidevice debugging master becomes a reality.  In this interactive talk you will learn how to deploy, use and run Vorlon.js.  See how it can help you remotely debug and test your JavaScript on multiple devices. Because after all, it’s a multidevice world, and development requires a multidevice debugging tool.

Bio: James is a Tech Evangelist for Microsoft.  He has been working in the web development space for 10+ years working with startups and enterprises to improve the way they do business through technology. James has extensive experience working with startups during the growth phase helping them deliver the product that their customers have asked for.  He is focused on automating development workflows that allow companies to achieve more.  When he isn’t practicing his software craft James can be found running through the woods, growing hops, or hiking with his daughter.


Vlad Balin

From Backbone to React: pure render with dirty models


Introducing new technologies in existing product is never easy. It's especially true when you deal with a large Backbone application, new technology is React, and you still have to deliver new features every month. Taking Volicon's experience as an example, we will discuss an approach which actually makes possible such a transition. We will talk about architectural differences and similarities between Backbone and React, how React can solve inherent problems of Backbone Views, and how to take full benefit of unidirectional data flow while keeping mutable OO models in data layer.


Bio: Vlad Balin is web front-end architect at Volicon, the leading provider of enterprise media intelligence solutions. He started building single-page JS application in 2010, having background in functional programming and asynchronous systems development in C++. At his current position in Volicon, Vlad is focused on making development of large-scale SPAs easier and safer. He is an author of experimental model framework NestedTypes (https://github.com/Volicon/NestedTypes), and number of React-related open-source projects.

We're a group of friendly folks who just love playing and getting together on a regular basis.  Our skills range from advanced beginner through experienced, and we're happy to help a 'newbie' or two learn the game.  Please bring a set if you have one; everyone will also need their own mah jong card.  Note that we will be playing American-style Mah jong, which is slightly different from Chinese mah jong.  American-style requires a mah jong card and uses jokers.  

We'd like to start the games at 6:30 promptly; feel free to come early and grab a bite from the Wegmans' cafe.  I'm typically upstairs around 6:00 to eat, meet, and greet!

Hope to see you on Tuesday nights!

--Jill

Come join us for our first weekly evening track workout! We'll be doing some speed intervals together plus short warm-up and cool-down runs to bookend them. Don't worry about how fast you are; all are welcome.

group.name: Dashing Whippets Running Team - Boston Chapter

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog
results.name: The Tuesday Track Workout

results.description:
Back by popular demand, we are hosting Speed Dating For Professionals!! Our previous events this year have been such a success, we are doing it again, and this time we have feed back on age preferences, so here we go...

Tired of online conversations that go nowhere? Profile pics from ten years ago? Does your thumb hurt from swiping? Can't understand why other speed dating events cost almost $40?

Want to just meet someone in person and have a real conversation??

Join us at Speed Dating for Professionals, brought to you by the crew at BostonYPA.com. The structure is simple:

1.) Arrive and relax during a mini happy hour - say hello, grab a drink.

2.) Enjoy several five minute dates with new faces. We will give you a question at each round to help get the conversation (and the laughter!) going. After five dates or so we will give you a quick break to get a refill, run to the loo, or even continue a conversation with the handsome stranger that was just sitting across from you.

3.) No need to swipe right or left - after your date is over, check off if you'd like to speak with them again. Within 24 hours (probably the same night since we will be so excited to send these out!) we will email participants the email address of matches. 4.) No matches? No problem. We will invite you back to our next speed dating event for free. Tickets: Ladies please buy a Ladies ticket, Gentleman please buy a Gentleman ticket. This allows us to get an even number of participants. Due to space and logistics, tickets for this event are limited to 30 Ladies and 30 Men. To help keep the numbers even, we will initially offer 20 of each, and once both genders hit the 20 count, increase tickets to 25, then 30. These events run best when there is balance to the room - if your ticket type is sold out, please DO NOT BUY THE OTHER TICKET. The bar will stay open after the speed dating is over so that the fun can continue.

https://speeddatingmarch2016.eventbrite.com

results.description:
Would you like to be able to relate authentically with ease? By authentic, we mean that you don’t have to worry or struggle about how you “should” be or what relating “should look like”. You can relax and be YOU.

Our lives are based around interaction and relating. How we communicate defines whether we will have relationships that are meaningful and supportive. Yet there are always times where communication breaks down, where connecting with another person (stranger or someone we know) seems like the hardest thing in the world.

What are AR Games?

Authentic Relating (AR) Games are a collection of extensively tested, masterfully facilitated experiences that give players a hands-on taste of both the joy and skills of interpersonal connection.

From meditative depths of presence and ecstatic heights of joy, to somber refelction and heart-pounding fun, the highly interactive games allow you to explore ways of seeing, connecting, and appreciating yourself and others at a deeper level.

Why Play?

Interacting in safe, spontaneous, fun ways invites us to practice the art of relating with others, playing a little more outside our comfort zones. 

- Learn to speak from what truly matters to you and ask for what you truly want

- Experience the absolute relief of being seen and accepted as we explore outside the box of social sleepwalking and superficial conversation 

- Create and foster conscious, deep connections and appreciate each other’s unique way of relating

What Should I Take?

A willingness to be curious, to extend your idea of yourself and others, to expand your perspective, to be moved by another person, to lean into your edge, to be surprised, to reflect, and to embrace the whole process.

What Can I Expect?

Laughter. Fun. Energy. More genuine connection. Anxiety/excitement (while learning the difference). Relief. Feeling alive and awake. Reverence. Conversation beyond small talk. New possibilities. New friends. Insights. Sparks. Challenges. Empowering. Transformation.

The skills I get to practice at games nights find their way organically into my life to enrich all my relationships with friends, family, workmates, even strangers on the street. ~NM

COST: $10

ALL SPOTS SECURED. Thank you for your interest. Look out for the next games night in April.

First timers to AR Games, we'll refund you $5 at the event as a thank you for coming to play with us ;0)

Only open to 26 folks. It will be sold out. RSVPs here do not reflect accurate registration numbers, nor do they secure your spot.

BONUS: 

Within a week or two, after Games Night, there'll be a phone call for all of us to bring questions and shares.

Why is it important for us to follow-up?  We understand how important it is to practice new learnings. We are committed to support your journey... to have wonderful, deeply satisfying relationships when you live from a "heart place" of authentic relating


Your Authentic Relating Facilitators:

ChewHoong and Nina Murrell

Trained in facilitating and guiding folks to notice, listen and reflect, to provide vocabulary/resources to be authentic, and the courage to actually do it.

We're passionate about fostering a community where the more we let ourselves relate authentically, the more we’ll be supported and deeply connected with each other.
results.name: AR: Authentic­ Relating with Ease and Deep Connection

Shamanic Journeying is a tool that has been traditionally used by indigenous shamans for the healing of individuals and communities. Shamans use drums and rattles to shift their consciousness into non-ordinary reality, a trance-like state, to communicate with their helping guides and spirits. We know now that anyone can learn to journey, to connect with their own helping guides and spirits in non- ordinary reality, in order to get answers to personal questions, solve problems, open creativity, see new ways of being in the world and obtain healing information for themselves and their community. Each participate will receive a Shamanic Blessings from Sue.

Please bring something for the alter, a journal and anything you would need to lay down with.

CALL, EMAIL OR TEXT Sue for information and registration:
[masked]
[masked]

Date: 

Every 2nd and 4th Tuesday of each month

Time: 7pm to 8 pm

Cost: $35

 Angelo created Shamanic Spirit Song over the past 10 years blending her natural intuitive gifts with her training as a Shamanic and Energy practitioner. Sue studies and practices Native America, Peruvian, and West Africa Traditions of Shamanism. She is certified by the Rhys Thomas Institute of Energy Medicine and is a certified Reiki Master. She worked in women’s health care for 30 years.

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.
results.name: Board Games in Sudbury

Prior to the Zen Center program at 7 PM is the Buddha' Belly Book Discussion Group at 6 PM.  The group will be reading and discussing Dan Goleman's new book, A Force for Good: The Dalai Lama's Vision for Our World.  OutBreathren who are interested are warmly invited to join the book discussion at 6.

Though not exclusively LGBTQ, this is a super LGBTQ-friendly event. The teacher/facilitator is ASC Senior Minister & uber-awesome lesbian, Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie. Rev. Crawford Harvie was previously minister of the UU Meeting House in Provincetown where she was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year. She teaches in the Zen Buddhist tradition.

http://www.ascboston.org/index.html

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Did you ever think about starting a tech company that builds websites? Do you already have a tech company that builds websites?


Join me for an introduction to using Drupal as a content management system (CMS). What are the benefits, what is the downside? How much do you need to know before you can build?


Drupal is free software built and created by a large and vibrant global community. We will take a look at how you can get started building sites with Drupal and how you can become a member of the Drupal community and travel the world!


There are DrupalCamps and events in many countries http://drupical.com will show you where a lot of them are happening.

Drupal is built for novices as well as experienced coders, there is a bit of a learning curve if you want to do something very customized, but you can build a beautiful site - right out of the box too!


I will show you how I created a company of freelancers using Drupal, without any coding experience.


Overview - Use Cases - Showcase - Q+A -- Get started building for FREE.


https://plus.google.com/hangouts/_/event/drupal?hl=en&authuser=0
results.name: Virtual Meetup:  Introduction to Drupal as a CMS

results.description:
Shylock Is My Name: Stephen Greenblatt and Howard Jacobson in Conversation
part of the Jewish Arts Festival

On the 500th Anniversary of the Venice Ghetto, acclaimed authors Stephen Greenblatt and Howard Jacobson talk about the legacy of its most famous resident—Shylock, the Jewish moneylender in Shakespeare’s The Merchant of Venice. Stephen Greenblatt is Cogan University Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University. He is the author of Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award winning The Swerve: How the World Became Modern, as well as numerous books on Shakespeare. Howard Jacobson is the author of more than a dozen novels, including Man Booker Prize winner The Finkler Question, The Mighty Walzer, and J. His new novel, Shylock Is My Name, is a contemporary retelling of The Merchant of Venice. They will be interviewed by Jonathan Wilson, Director of the Tufts University Center for the Humanities.

Actors from the Commonwealth Shakespeare Company will perform a staged reading of selected scenes from Merchant of Venice.

Presented in partnership with Commonwealth Shakespeare Company

Use code 2for1 to get two tickets for the price of one. https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe/10065740
results.name: Shylock Is My Name: Stephen Greenblatt and Howard Jacobson in Conversation

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.name: Mindfulness Meditation

results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

If you're a lover, not a fighter, but you or your lover like it a little rough, let America's favorite sex geek (and double black belt), Reid Mihalko of ReidAboutSex.com, show you how you can safely be a bad ass in bed.

From wrestling to rough sex to advanced ergonomic techniques, join us for this humorous and informative workshop (with demos!) on how to unleash your inner Bruce Lee of the bedroom. In this class for all genders and orientations, Reid will cover: rough sex for nice guys; the best sex positions; proper body positioning and ergonomics for harder, stronger, longer sex; why and how wrestling can be a turn-on; wrestling techniques that are safe, easy, and fun; hair-pulling 101; how to move your partner's body around the bed with more ease; and much more!

No matter your experience level, orientation, relationship status, this class is going to be educational, fun, and give you some delicious bedroom Kung-Fu.

Sit and watch as Reid demonstrates how easy it is to be a black belt at sex! We'll even have plenty of room for your questions! Join us! Bring friends! Bring a notebook!


When you attend, please make a point to let Good Vibrations know that you heard about this event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup.


==> Get Tickets Here.

results.description:
So the official league play of this excellent game has already tipped off, but some of us (OK, I) have a fever for the flavor of more Food Chain Magnate. If you're in the same boat and want to take on the challenge, this is your chance.

PLEASE NOTE: I am specifically looking to start a FAST game, ideally one where we're getting through at least 1-2 turns per day. If you're only able to get online and submit your moves once per day, please don't sign up for this event!

On the other hand, complete newbies are OK, if you're able to assimilate the rules quick-like and learn by doing without getting discouraged by the inevitable rookie mistakes.

Those new to the Boardgamecore site should be aware that the site DOES NOT send automatic e-mail reminders when it's your turn, unlike the sites we use for other online games. Please check to see if it's your turn as often as you can while still being a functional adult!
results.name: Online Food Chain Magnate (Fast Players, Please!)

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

To Register for This Event, You Must Click Here 

It is the third time we are doing Google Q&A. 

First one was very popular and not only among participants. 

Second one attracted the attention of such highly ranking experts as Barry Schwartz. 

1 of Google’s Senior Strategist and 4 universally known SEO experts, they have nothing to prove, just get/share some new ideas and surely enjoy the moment. It was fun first time, it was great second time, could it go better? There is only one way to find out: Join us!

More information about the speakers:

WebPromo.Expert - Anton Shulke - marketing manager - Twitter @WebPromoExperts

I host 2-3 SEO webinars a week, had Gianluca Fiorelli, Joe Pulizzi, Stewart Ryan, Steve Rayson, Ammon Johns, Bill Slawski, Eric Enge here. And many others

Google - Andrey Lipattsev - Search Quality Senior Strategist - Twitter @googlewmc

Andrey Lipattsev – Search Quality Senior Strategist at Google (Ireland). Andrey has been with Google since August 2010, starting as Search Quality Associate. He graduated from King’s St. Joseph’s Hall College, Oxford, UK/Universidad de Oviedo, Spain/Hull University, UK/Grenoble Graduate School of Business, France. He speaks 5 languages: Russian, English, Spanish, German and French.

Moz - Rand Fishkin - Wizard of Moz - Twitter @randfish

Moz founder. Forbes put Rand in “Top 15 SEO Gurus 2015

Ammon Johns & Co - Ammon Johns - Managing Director - Twitter @Ammon_Johns

Ammon Johns – innovative Online Marketing and SEO Pioneer. Ammon is Managing Director at Ammon Johns & Co. Lives in Newhaven(UK)

To Register for This Event, You Must Click Here

results.description:
Glitter Tower and Castle's 3D Cosplay

invite you to join us before Anime Boston for a night of movies, food, and dancing, as we celebrate the wonderful works of Studio Ghibli!


LINK TO THE FACEBOOK PAGE EVENT WHERE YOU CAN OBTAIN TICKETS:

https://www.facebook.com/events/149602805416268/


ALL AGES!

FILM SCHEDULE:

3pm - Kiki's Delivery Service

5pm - My Neighbor Totoro + Dinner

7pm - Howl's Moving castle

9pm - Spirited Away + Dance

TICKETS:

There are two types of tickets for this event:

Potluck Tickets - $13

You're totally into the theme and want to share that passion with everyone! We can't all be as awesome as you, but we sure love you anyway. (You promise to bring a Studio Ghibli themed potluck dish to share with 3-4 people and you can help yourself to a slice or two of pizza to go with it!)

Pizza Tickets - $18

You're a hardcore fan, but sometimes life gets complicated and it's just not possible to cook AND get your cosplay perfect. We got you. That's why pizza was invented after all. (We'll provide the pizza, plus you'll get to sample some of the potluck dishes)

FAQ:


If I sign up for "x" ticket, is that all I can eat?


-Nope. ALL food will be shared by ALL people. You're not locking yourself into a dinner, just into cooking.

Can I drink alcohol at the event?


-Not this time. Due to venue restrictions and weird liquor laws, we're not allowed to bring or sell alcohol on the premesis. Please don't try and sneak a flask or you'll be kindly asked to leave without a refund. We're working on making this a reality in the future though, so stay tuned!

Is Cosplay allowed?


-ABSOLUTELY! Not just allowed, but highly encouraged! We're even going to have a contest for the best theme cosplay, so break out the glue gun and get crafting!

Can I bring my cosplay props?


-Absolutely! If there aren't at least two Kiki's running around on brooms, we'll be sad. Unfortunately, due to venue restrictions, we can't allow live steel or projectile weapons, so leave those NERF guns and katanas at home.

Do I need to know how to Waltz or Cha-Cha for the dance?


-Nope! No formal dance this time. A long running staple of anime cons the world over, Happy Hardcore is *the* hard hitting beat to lift your spirits and get your feet moving and

DJ Nick Castle

spins until the very end.

But I wanted to see "insert other Studio Ghibli movie here!"


-While we're working on breaking into the Minstry to get a Time Turner, we've had no luck just yet and are unfortunately bound by the normal conventions of time and space. That means we have to pick and choose the films that will fit neatly into our time slots. Don't worry though, this won't be the last event we throw.Recent Posts
results.name: SOLD OUT STUDIO GHIBLI THEMED DINNER & DANCE

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

Admission to the MFA (The Boston Museum of Fine Arts) is free after 4pm on Wednesdays!!

We get together in the Longwood Medical Area on Tuesday evenings for bilingual chat, but just a few blocks away is one of the world's finest art museums (and it also has a section on Sinology or China studies).

This would be a host-free meetup where you 'just go' and bring friends, if you wish. I suggest that our group bring different small groups of bilinguals with China interest to the MFA, and make that a topic of discussion.

The Massachusetts Medical Device Development Center (M2D2) will be hosting the 5th Annual M2D2 $100K Challenge Showcase Event on Wednesday, March 23, 2016. Novel bio-tech and medical device technologies will be presented, followed by a poster and networking session. You also will have the opportunity to speak with current member companies and M2D2 Tenants clients already taking advantage of M2D2's benefits and services.

This showcase event is for Inventors, Entrepreneurs, Small Businesses, future applicants as well as investors in the bio-tech and medical device industries.

The event will feature presentations and posters by the Bio-Tech and Medical Device start-up companies and inventors, featuring new bio-tech and medical device design inventions and technologies that have been submitted to the 5th Annual M2D2 $100K Challenge.

The presenting finalists will compete for a chance to win a total of $100,000 in services or grant awards from the Challenge sponsors from BD (Becton Dickinson and Company), Boston Scientific, Mintz Levin, MPR Product Development, Omni Components and R&Q (Regulatory & Quality Solutions). Come see the new bio-tech and medical device ventures that will be showcased and enjoy a night of valuable networking!

REGISTER: https://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/eventReg?oeidk=a07ec94egxud71e98fe&oseq=&c=&ch=

Registration Fee until March 9, 2016: $30.00 and includes Hor D'Oeuvres, Beer & Wine

results.description:
Are you seeking effective marketing strategies?  Do you have limited time and resources?  

The Brookline Chamber of Commerce, the Brookline Interactive Group (BIG), <a>Constant Contact</a> and Nicastro Consultants are sponsoring a series of marketing workshops at BIG.

The 2016 #beamarketer workshops are designed to facilitate and support a dialog among business owners.  Participants will learn how to:

-create a marketing play book

-plan an effective marketing strategy

-implement your marketing strategy

-manage marketing initiatives

You’ll also gain an understanding of your thresholds for when to “do it yourself,” “do it with help” or “have someone do it for you.”  

Many small businesses and organizations find themselves seeking the right strategies to make their marketing efforts as effective as possible.  But with so many different marketing activities that they could focus on, they often miss some of the important marketing concepts that will help them understand why those activities are so important.  

This presentation is designed to uncover some of those core concepts and show that a little bit of marketing knowledge can go a long way.  

Attendees of this presentation will learn: 

•  What marketing really is (and isn’t)

•  How marketing has changed in ways that benefit small businesses.

•  The importance of setting goals and objectives for their marketing efforts. 

•  The 4 Pillars or Marketing Success – a framework that shows how different marketing activities all fit together, and will help small businesses reflect on their own marketing program. 

•  It’s ok to start small, to start where you already are.

Presented by Heather Jackson of Constant Contact and Doreen Nicastro of Nicastro Consultants. Read about Heather and Doreen at business.brooklinechamber.com/events/details/what-you-need-to-know-about-digital-marketing-for-the-next-12-months-866
results.name: Build Your Marketing Toolkit

Ralph is currently a Test Engineer at Transperfect. He has experience with Java, TestNG, JUnit, Selenium, Rest Assured, Selenium Grid and Jenkins, but the talk is abstract and applies to most automation scenarios. He has 18 years of experience in software testing. Previously he was at IBM working on  Lotus Domino/Notes, Lotus Domino/Notes in the cloud, IBM Connections and Watson.

7:50pm-8pm - Final announcements

results.description:
This event will consist of a series of "Lightning Talks" from several different speakers. Each speaker receives fifteen minutes to present.

This is a wonderful opportunity for Boston PHP members to step out from the audience and into the spotlight. First time presenters are welcome and encouraged.

Talk submissions have already been selected for this event, but we tend to do an event like this a few times each year, so if you have a topic you'd like to hear about or if you'd like to submit a talk yourself, don't give up hope! Just keep an eye out for the next one.


Thank you to our speakers who have volunteered to speak.

Here are our speakers & topics.
(This sequence may change at the event)

Benji Fisher -  Ansible - Radically Simple IT Automation

Simon Sorich - Event Sourcing and CQRS

Andrew Curioso - PHP development environment with Docker

James Sturdevant - Debugging PHP with VS Code


Aaron Bieber - Escaping the Tar Pit: Principles of Continuous Improvement

Mike Toppa - 10 Tips for clean code

Mark Holt - PHP & PMC


Agenda


6:00 PM - 7:00 PM -- Pizza and refreshments compliments of our generous sponsor

7:00 PM - 7:15 PM -- General Announcements

7:15 PM - 8:45 PM -- Lightning Talk Speakers

8:45 PM - ??? -- Afterparty at Champions Bar
results.name: Lightning Talks

results.description:
Charleene's Country Line Dance Lessons take place Wednesdays in Weymouth (OR Angela hosts the Tuesdays in Braintree) and she has a great team helping her teach the classes. Beginner lessons @ 6-7pm and Advanced lessons @ 7-8pm. This is a fun way to learn several country line dances with others and get in a nice workout. You'll then be able to join in the fun when you are out and see other people line dancing. 

What to Bring/Wear:

~Water (they do not provide drinks and you will get thirsty)

~Cowboy Boots (if you have them), boots or shoes w/ heels; no sneakers!

~Comfy Clothes (remember, you're dancing!)

Cost is $10 cash ONLY.

Please plan to arrive a few minutes early if this is your first time attending. This way you can pay at the register and we can get introduced before the fun starts.

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD; FYI - This happens weekly and they don't dance if the governor says to stay off the road.


Parking: Free and ample parking on-site.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in the main entrence in the big room on the left but sometimes they are in the smaller room on the right.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

The Revolve Nation's Boston Entrepreneurs Network is the largest community of entrepreneurs and business owners in the city of Boston, offering networking, discussion groups, seminars, business plan hot-seats, and more!

Join us here, where professionals and entrepreneurs meet in mutual support of business to network, socialize, learn, and promote a thriving community of entrepreneurs. Wine and snacks provided!

Schedule:

6pm-6:30pm  -- Open Networking over wine and snacks

6:30-6:45pm  -- Meeting Called to Order and Introductions

6:45--7:45pm -- Open discussions on topics of interest to our members (examples; Getting funded, building a team, using mailing lists and their effectiveness, firing a difficult employee) Suggest your own topics as comments on the event, or simply bring them with you!

7:45-8:00pm  -- More Networking! (and wine!)

Like anything in life, what you put into a networking group is what you get out of it. The Boston Entrepreneurs Group is designed for entrepreneurs and professionals who are serious about building their business, investing in relationships, and helping each other to succeed.

The way the group seeks to achieve these outcomes:

1) Regular attendance

2) Dedication to coming prepared to contribute value to the community with expertise, experience, and networks.

3) Create a fun and supportive environment!

Price: FREE

SPONSORS: Revolve, Inc.: www.revolvethis.com

Exemplar Law: www.exemplarcompanies.com

See you soon!

results.description:
This session covers the nuts and bolts of real estate investing, and draws on interviews with local investors and lenders. We'll review several real-life examples of completed projects (a condo conversion and a "buy and hold" property) and work through one possible investment together.

This workshop is very interactive and useful both for those looking to get started in real estate investing and people who own a few properties and want to get more information. We'll talk about the tax aspects of real estate investing, present a financing overview, and discuss skills needed and "lessons learned" from local investors.

Following the workshop, I'll provide attendees with a link to the full presentation and to numerous additional resources for locating, evaluating, and closing investments.

results.description:
The book is A Mad, Wicked Folly by Sharon Briggs Waller.

For Women’s History month, let’s read some historical fiction.

Welcome to the world of the fabulously wealthy in London, 1909, where dresses and houses are overwhelmingly opulent, social class means everything, and women are taught to be nothing more than wives and mothers. Into this world comes seventeen-year-old Victoria Darling, who wants only to be an artist—a nearly impossible dream for a girl.
After Vicky poses nude for her art class, she is expelled from her French finishing school. Shamed and scandalized, her parents try to marry her off to the wealthy Edmund Carrick-Humphrey. But Vicky has other things on her mind: her clandestine application to the Royal College of Art; her participation in the suffragette movement; and her growing attraction to a working-class boy who may be her muse—or may be the love of her life. As the world of debutante balls, corsets, and high society obligations closes in around her, Vicky must figure out: just how much is she willing to sacrifice to pursue her dreams?

The venue is Pho Hoa in Chinatown, a reasonably priced Vietnamese restaurant with nice, round tables and a quieter atmosphere.
results.name: A Mad, Wicked Folly at Pho Hoa in Chinatown

The reason for this is we want to make sure the students who attend the sessions from the beginning are not held up by potential students who miss the lesson from the previous classes.*


You wonder what level is the most appropriate for you? If you struggle with staying on beat/rhythm,you know very little about combination, musicality, or this is a new experience for you I will highly suggest level 1. Level 2 you will learn more difficult turn patterns and footwork but if you are not ready for level 2 you will be kindly asked to drop down to level 1. results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

RSVP now for Wed, Mar 23 - Learn valuable do's and don'ts for addressing an audience. Listen to first-time speakers. And discover how to get over that "anxiety hurdle."

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time (and returning) guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Wed, March  23, (6:45 PM)

[No Saturday session for April. Sorry.]

You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
This listing is for informational purposes only and is not a hosted Mountaineering, Climbing & Backpacking of NE meetup event. 

Namuli Film + Presentation by Majka Burhardt

There are two showings/separate dates:

**March 19, 2016: IME, North Conway, NH - $10 All donations to Legado: People and ecosystems thriving together.  Doors open for social hour at 6pm. Film & Stories at 7pm

**March 23, 2016: Patagonia, Boston, MA - FREE. Social hour and food 6pm. Film 7:30pm

Namuli is a community-backed film about the spirit of exploration and what happens when a team of rock climbers, biologists, and conservationists set off on an unconventional expedition into one of the world’s least-explored and most-threatened habitats.

The film follows an international crew as they push the bounds of friendship, climbing conventions, and scientific research on the 2,000-foot granite face of Mozambique’s second highest mountain, Mount Namuli.

The film features expedition leader Majka Burhardt, a professional climber, author, and social entrepreneur, professional climber Kate Rutherford, Brazilian entomologist Flavia Esteves, South African entomologist Caswell Munyai, and Mozambican herpetologist Harith Farooq.

More Information: http://www.legadoinitiative.org/namuli-film/
results.name: Namuli - The Film

results.description:
If you're doing anything where you are working with people, you need to know how to clear your energy field. 


Symptoms of a Gummed-up Energy Field 

1) Feeling tired all the time 
2) Headaches 
3) Confusion and Inability to Focus 
4) Unexpected or unexplained reactions from others 
5) Inability to access any of the Chakra centers 
6) Feeling unsafe or ungrounded 
7) Feeling weak or victimized for no good reason 
8) Sudden shifts in sense of well being 
9) Intuition either on overdrive or shut down 
10) Disrupted sleep patterns

Energetic hygiene is of critical importance. You wouldn't go weeks without a shower, you shouldn't go weeks without clearing your energy field. You won't believe the difference in how you feel when you start doing this regularly. 

You'll Learn:

1) Several different ways to clear your energy field 
2) Multiple ways to clear your home and/or work space 
3) Good energetic hygiene practices 
4) Boundaries to maintain your energetic clarity
results.name: HBS-Melrose: Clear Your Energy Field

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night

results.description:
Please RSVP! (E51-315  - 70 Memorial Dr. Cambridge, MA - map and parking info at bottom of announcement.

Where Will the Market Go From Here?

  By Rich Gula, President Argyle Investments

Rich Gula will return to discuss what he sees in the market, from a bottom up approach.  The market is flat year- to- date.  What’s working now?

Nobody knows what will happen in the market.  But Rich will use his quantitative asset allocation model to show what we should buy now – countries, commodities, what else?  No Apple, no Facebook.  What happened to GOPRO?

Since 1999, Argyle Investments, LLC has created customized valuation models for hedge funds and investment managers.  More recently, Argyle has designed short=term risk-averse trading models to exploit the increasing uncertainty surrounding market prospects and equity valuations in an environment in which interest rates are likely rising. 

Previously, Rich served as director of technical analysis at Fidelity Management and Research.  At Fidelity, he developed quantitative and technical research strategies, which were integrated into the firm’s security selection process.  He had formerly had key roles in various investment firms as chief investment officer, head of international equities, and director of market analysis.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MIT Building E51  is located at 70 Memorial Dr, but the entrance is at 2 Amherst St (put that in your GPS).   The best parking is in the "elbow" of Building E51, and there is also good parking at the Hayward St lot, about a block West.

Here is a map link: http://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E51

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have a friend you talk stocks with, bring them with you! Food or drinks are not allowed in any MIT meeting room. We strongly urge each person to make his or her own decisions about investing their money. Investment ideas and recommendations made during our meetings and in our online dialogs bear no liability by anyone. This is a free and open meeting. No membership is required, but please RSVP.
results.name: Boston Investor's Group Wednesday Meetup

venue.name: Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill-Somerville

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we discuss Bastiat's famous political essay "The Candlemaker's Petition."

Like America today, France in the 19th century faced ridiculously cheap imports from a large foreign producer that was destroying jobs. Read Bastiat's novel proposal to stimulate the domestic economy and protect French jobs.

Please note the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], our Director of Events, with any questions.

QUESTIONS:

1.) Do cheap foreign goods put some domestic workers out of a job?

2.) Do cheap foreign goods bring down the price of domestic goods and thus domestic wages in the industries that compete with foreign goods?

3.) Can jobs be protected in some industries by imposing a tariff?

4.) What are the economic effects of a tariff?

5.) What is the seen, and what is the unseen, when it comes to protectionism?

6.) Is the large foreign producer that Bastiat talks about "dumping"?

7.) What does it mean when free trade treaties outlaw "dumping"?

8.) If there was a free trade treaty with the Sun that outlawed dumping and punished it with retaliatory tariffs, would this look any different than Bastiat's proposed sunlight tax?

9.) Some people are proposing "automation taxes", whereby employer who automate jobs have to contribute a larger tax burden to pay for unemployment programs. Would this have the same effect as a tariff or sunlight tax?

10.) Which countries around the world nowadays have banned the sun, partially or in full?
results.name: The Candlemakers Petition

Do I need to change my job, move my home, or make other such huge changes to bring purpose into my life? Drawing attention to the mind and changing the way you see and interact with the world can bring a sense of personal fulfillment that transcends the details of your daily life.

Learn to live with meaning!

results.description:
This is a free meditation session, and an introduction to the Art of Living course, meant to bring people together for a few moments of perfect tranquility in the heart of Cambridge. Join us as we practice meditation and mindfulness, and hang around later to interact with like-minded people over a relaxing cup of tea. These sessions are being offered by the Art of Living Foundation, a non-profit organization engaged in service initiatives across 153 countries. So, come, empty your minds, and fill up your teacups!

No meditation experience required, all are welcome. Please RSVP!
results.name: Meditation & Tea

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: 

https://hangouts.google.com/hangouts/_/daviddrayton.com/weeklyautomatedincomemastermindmeeting

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
“Detox” is a trendy word these days, and there are lots of products on the market that promise to “chelate your heavy metals” and “cleanse your colon”. But what does that mean? What are toxins, and how can we really clear them from the body? Are fasts, cleanses, and laxatives really necessary? When it comes to detox, there are some details you should know before you begin—to make the process safer, more effective, and longer-lasting.

Burdock is one of the gentlest, yet most reliable, detoxifying herbs in our materia medica.

Come find out why restoring healthy liver function is a critical step in any detoxification program. Learn simple and sustainable methods for eliminating toxins from your food, body, and environment. Understand the importance of sleep, movement, and diet in an effective detox protocol, and why it’s imperative that we nourish before we purge. And learn about herbs that help to clean the blood, support the liver, and restore your body’s natural pathways of elimination and detoxification.

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday
